conceptual-software-flaws.title: Conceptual Software Flaws (historically grown, hard to maintain)
conceptual-software-flaws.description: As software grows in functionality, its code often becomes more complex. If the code is not properly structured based on a sound software architecture, it can be very difficult to maintain.
conceptual-software-flaws.impact: The primary impact is an increased likelihood of unpatched or unpatchable vulnerabilities, which can be exploited to compromise the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of the system and its data.
conceptual-software-flaws.asvs: V1 Architecture, Design and Threat Modeling Requirements
conceptual-software-flaws.mitigation: For new development, establish and enforce a clear software architecture that emphasizes modularity, separation of concerns, and maintainability.
conceptual-software-flaws.check: Is the software architecture for custom-developed components clearly documented? Is the code modular and testable?
conceptual-software-flaws.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for all in-scope, custom-developed technical assets.
conceptual-software-flaws.riskAssessment: The impact is determined by the confidentiality and criticality of the asset and the data it processes or stores. An unmaintainable system handling mission-critical data poses a very high risk.
conceptual-software-flaws.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive if a

insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.title: Insufficient Software Testing and Release Procedures (related to BSI CON.1/CON.3)
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.description: If new software is not sufficiently tested and formally released, critical errors and security vulnerabilities may go undetected.
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.impact: Failure to adequately test software can lead to the disclosure, manipulation, or destruction of sensitive information.
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein CON.1 (General Software Development) and CON.3 (Software Tests).
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.action: Implement and Enforce a Secure Software Development Lifecycle (SSDLC)
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.mitigation: Establish a formal process for testing and releasing all custom-developed software components. This process should include mandatory security testing, such as Static Application Security Testing (SAST),
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.check: Is there a documented testing strategy for custom-developed software? Are security testing tools integrated into the CI/CD pipeline?
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.detectionLogic: This risk is triggered for all in-scope, custom-developed technical assets that are of a type that typically contains complex business logic (e.g., web applications, web services, application servers).
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.riskAssessment: The likelihood of exploitation is directly related to the complexity of the custom code and the lack of a structured testing process.
insufficient-software-testing-and-releas.falsePositives: A risk might be flagged for a component that is covered by a comprehensive, organization-wide testing process that is explicitly modeled.

testing-with-production-data.title: Testing with Production Data (BSI CON.1.A15)
testing-with-production-data.description: When new software is tested using production data, unauthorized individuals (e.g., developers, testers) may gain access to confidential information, such as sensitive personal data.
testing-with-production-data.impact: If this risk materializes, it can lead to severe data breaches (Confidentiality), data corruption (Integrity), and service outages (Availability).
testing-with-production-data.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz CON.1.A15 (Separation of test and production data)
testing-with-production-data.action: Use Anonymized, Pseudonymized, or Synthetic Data for Testing
testing-with-production-data.mitigation: Strictly separate test and production environments. Establish and enforce a policy that prohibits the use of real production data in test environments.
testing-with-production-data.check: Is there a documented policy for test data management? Are test and production environments logically and physically separated? What processes are in place to generate safe test data (anonymization, synthesis)? How is access to test environments controlled and monitored?
testing-with-production-data.detectionLogic: This risk is identified when a technical asset that appears to be in a test or development context processes or stores sensitive production-grade data.
testing-with-production-data.riskAssessment: The impact is directly related to the confidentiality and integrity rating of the production data asset being used. A high impact is assumed if

interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.title: Interruption of Data Transmission (BSI CON.1)
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.description: Information exchange can be disturbed, delayed, or completely interrupted due to technical failures or performance bottlenecks in communication links or their connected components.
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.impact: If information is not delivered on time, is incomplete, or is not delivered at all, business processes that depend on this data can be significantly impaired or fail completely.
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.asvs: Related to OWASP ASVS V1 Architectural Requirements, particularly V1.11 for availability and resiliency design.
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.action: Implement Resilient and Performant Communication Channels
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.mitigation: Ensure that data with high-availability requirements is transmitted over resilient communication channels.
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.check: Are communication links for critical systems designed for high availability? Are the technical assets involved in the data transmission (source and target) marked as redundant? Is there active monitoring of link performance and error rates?
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.detectionLogic: This risk is triggered for communication links that are critical for availability but show signs of being a single point of failure.
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.riskAssessment: The impact is determined by the highest availability requirement of the data being transferred or the assets involved. The likelihood is based on the lack of redundancy of the participating assets. A non-redundant component handling mission-critical data poses a significant availability risk.
interruption-of-data-transmission-con1.falsePositives: The model may not capture all forms of physical or network-level redundancy (e.g., BGP, diverse fiber paths) that are not explicitly modeled as separate components.

missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.title: Risk of Data Misuse due to Missing or Inadequate Confidentiality Agreement (related to BSI CON.7)
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.description: Sensitive information can fall into the hands of unauthorized persons if a confidentiality agreement (e.g., an NDA) was not concluded or was poorly formulated before an information exchange with an external party. This lack of a formal agreement increases the risk of data misuse, as there are no binding rules on how the external party can handle the received information.
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.impact: Without a clear and binding confidentiality agreement, sensitive data exchanged with external parties can be misused, disclosed, or handled improperly. This can lead to a breach of confidentiality, reputational damage, competitive disadvantage, and potential legal or financial penalties, especially if personal or business-critical data is involved.
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein CON.7 (Exchange of information). Requirement CON.7.A3 (Agreements on information transfer) requires establishing formal transfer policies, procedures, and controls.
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.action: Establish and Enforce Confidentiality Agreements for External Data Exchange
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.mitigation: For any communication link with an external entity that involves the transfer of sensitive data (rated
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.check: Review all communication links to/from assets of type
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.detectionLogic: This rule checks all communication links that connect to a technical asset of type `external-entity`. If such a link transfers data with a confidentiality rating of
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.riskAssessment: The impact of this risk is directly proportional to the confidentiality level of the data being exchanged. The likelihood is considered high if no agreement is in place, as there is no formal barrier to misuse. The highest confidentiality level of the data assets transferred over the communication link determines the impact.
missing-confidentiality-agreement-con7.falsePositives: A risk might be flagged if a confidentiality agreement exists but has not been documented in the model using the `@nda-signed` tag. It can also be a false positive if the data exchange is covered by a broader Master Service Agreement (MSA) specific to this individual link.

accidental-data-leakage.title: Accidental Data Leakage (based on BSI Threat Description)
accidental-data-leakage.description: Sensitive information can be inadvertently sent to unauthorized recipients due to human error, insufficient training, or a lack of clear procedures. Examples include sending data to the wrong email address, or transmitting documents that contain hidden residual information (like internal comments or insufficiently deleted data).
accidental-data-leakage.impact: This can lead to a breach of confidentiality for sensitive data, resulting in non-compliance with legal or contractual requirements (like @DataType:PII), reputational damage, and financial loss.
accidental-data-leakage.asvs: Related to concepts in BSI IT-Grundschutz CON.1 (General data protection) and DER.1 (Detection of security-related events).
accidental-data-leakage.action: Implement Controls for Data in Transit
accidental-data-leakage.mitigation: Use Data Loss Prevention (DLP) tools to monitor and block unauthorized transmission of sensitive information. Enforce strong authorization on communication channels, especially for external-facing protocols like email. Implement data sanitization to strip metadata and comments from files before they are sent. Provide regular, targeted training to all personnel on secure data handling procedures and how to identify and protect sensitive information.
accidental-data-leakage.check: Are data-in-transit controls (like DLP) in place for sensitive data flows? Are file-sharing and email protocols properly secured and access-controlled? Does the organization provide mandatory, regular training on data handling and classification?
accidental-data-leakage.detectionLogic: This risk is identified by analyzing communication links that transfer sensitive data (Confidentiality of
accidental-data-leakage.riskAssessment: The impact is directly rated based on the confidentiality of the data being transferred (e.g.,
accidental-data-leakage.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive if there are out-of-band compensating controls in place, such as a separate, mandatory DLP gateway that scans all outgoing email, or if the specific data flow is highly proceduralized and automated, reducing the chance of human error.

unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.title: Unprotected Data In-Transit or At-Rest (BSI CON.1, SYS.1.6)
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.description: Information and data can be surreptitiously intercepted (Information Disclosure) or altered (Tampering) if not adequately protected.
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.impact: Successful exploitation leads to the loss of confidentiality and/or integrity of the affected data. Attackers can steal sensitive information (e.g., credentials, personal data, business secrets), inject malicious content (like malware into file transfers), or manipulate critical data. This can result in data breaches, financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences.
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz: CON.1 (General data transmission), SYS.1.6 (Servers under Windows and Linux). Maps to OWASP ASVS V5: V9.1 (Communications) and V7.2 (Cryptographic Storage).
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.action: Enforce Encryption for Data In-Transit and At-Rest
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.mitigation: All communication links transmitting data across trust boundaries MUST use a strong, encrypted protocol (e.g., TLS 1.3+, HTTPS, SFTP, WSS, encrypted database protocols).
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.check: Review all communication links in the architecture. Do they use an encrypted protocol, especially when crossing trust boundaries or transmitting sensitive data?
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.detectionLogic: This rule identifies risks in two scenarios:
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.riskAssessment: The likelihood of exploitation is higher for data in-transit over untrusted networks (like the internet). The impact is directly proportional to the sensitivity (CIA rating) of the data being transmitted or stored. Transmitting
unprotected-data-in-transit-or-at-rest-b.falsePositives: A communication link might be part of a physically secured, isolated network where the risk of interception is considered acceptable.

unencrypted-transmission.title: Unencrypted Transmission of Sensitive Data
unencrypted-transmission.description: The protection of information during transmission using cryptographic methods can be undermined by attacks. If cryptographic methods are not applied correctly, an attacker can intercept and access the transmitted data. This is especially true if sensitive data is sent over an unencrypted communication channel across a trust boundary. The BSI warns that inadequately protected communication can lead to data interception and manipulation.
unencrypted-transmission.impact: If sensitive data is transmitted unencrypted, it can be intercepted and read (loss of confidentiality) or modified (loss of integrity) by an attacker with access to the communication path. This can lead to data breaches, unauthorized access to systems, financial loss, and reputational damage.
unencrypted-transmission.asvs: V9.1: Verify that all communications between components are encrypted in transit.
unencrypted-transmission.mitigation: Ensure that all communication links carrying sensitive data across trust boundaries use strong, encrypted protocols (e.g., HTTPS, TLS, SFTP, JDBC-encrypted). Disable weak cipher suites. Use a VPN as a compensating control if the native protocol cannot be encrypted. Ensure keys are managed securely and separately from the data they protect.
unencrypted-transmission.check: Are all communication links between different trust boundaries using an encrypted protocol? Is a VPN used for unencrypted protocols? Are there any links carrying confidential or critical data that are unencrypted?
unencrypted-transmission.detectionLogic: This rule checks for communication links that cross trust boundaries and are not encrypted (i.e., do not use a protocol like HTTPS, TLS, etc.) and are not protected by a VPN. The risk is raised if these links transmit data with a confidentiality level higher than
unencrypted-transmission.riskAssessment: The likelihood is influenced by the network exposure (e.g., internet vs. internal) and compensating controls like IP filtering. The impact is determined by the highest confidentiality and integrity of the data assets transmitted over the link.
unencrypted-transmission.falsePositives: The risk might be a false positive if other, un-modeled compensating controls are in place (e.g., a hardware-based network encryptor). It can also be considered a false positive for certain monitoring or security protocols that intentionally operate on unencrypted traffic within a controlled environment.

malicious-code-execution-in-browser.title: Malicious Code Execution in Web Browser
malicious-code-execution-in-browser.description: Web browsers regularly load data from untrusted sources. Such data can contain executable malicious code that exploits vulnerabilities and infects the user
malicious-code-execution-in-browser.impact: If malicious code is executed via the browser, an attacker can compromise the client system. This can lead to theft of sensitive data (Information Disclosure), manipulation of data or system files (Tampering), or installation of ransomware (Denial of Service).
malicious-code-execution-in-browser.action: Implement and Enforce Browser and Endpoint Security Hardening
malicious-code-execution-in-browser.mitigation: Ensure browsers are kept up-to-date with the latest security patches through a managed process. Disable or restrict unnecessary or risky plugins and extensions.
malicious-code-execution-in-browser.check: Are all client web browsers centrally managed and automatically updated? Is there a policy for allowed/disallowed browser extensions? Are security configurations for browsers enforced? Is an endpoint protection solution with browser security features active?
malicious-code-execution-in-browser.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for any in-scope technical asset identified with the
malicious-code-execution-in-browser.falsePositives: This risk is fundamental to using a web browser for general internet access. It can be considered a false positive only in rare cases where the browser is used in an extremely restricted

exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.title: Exploitation of Client-Side Vulnerabilities
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.description: Vulnerability lists and exploit kits significantly simplify the development of custom malware.
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.impact: If client-side vulnerabilities are successfully exploited, attackers can install malware (like ransomware, spyware, or keyloggers) on the client system.
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz: SYS.2.1 Web Browser, SYS.1.2.2 Client under Windows, SYS.1.3 Client under macOS
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.action: Implement Client Hardening, Patch Management, and Endpoint Protection
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.mitigation: Keep client operating systems, browsers, and all extensions/plugins up-to-date with the latest security patches.
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.check: Are client systems and browsers centrally managed and kept up-to-date with security patches? Is a modern EDR/antivirus solution deployed and active on all clients?
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.detectionLogic: This risk is triggered for all in-scope technical assets identified as client systems (e.g., technology types: Browser, Desktop, Mobile App, etc.).
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.riskAssessment: The likelihood of exploitation is very high for unmanaged client systems connected to the internet, as they are exposed to automated scanning and drive-by attacks.
exploitation-of-client-side-vulnerabilit.falsePositives: This risk may be a false positive if robust, centrally-managed compensating controls (like a comprehensive EDR, strict application whitelisting, or a non-persistent VDI environment) are in place but n@SystemType:OT modeled.

insecure-communication-over-internet.title: Insecure Communication over the Internet
insecure-communication-over-internet.description: The fundamental security of communication over the internet depends significantly on the authentication methods used and the encryption of data in transit.
insecure-communication-over-internet.impact: If communication is not effectively secured, sensitive information can be intercepted (violating Confidentiality) or modified in transit (violating Integrity).
insecure-communication-over-internet.action: Enforce Strong Authentication and Encryption for Communication
insecure-communication-over-internet.mitigation: All communication links, especially those crossing trust boundaries or carrying sensitive data, must use strong, state-of-the-art encrypted protocols (e.g., using TLS 1.2/1.3, SSH).
insecure-communication-over-internet.check: Review all communication links in the model. Verify that any link carrying sensitive data or crossing a trust boundary uses an encrypted protocol (e.g., HTTPS, FTPS, WSS, LDAPS, etc.).
insecure-communication-over-internet.detectionLogic: This rule checks all communication links in the model. It triggers a risk if a link uses an unencrypted protocol, especially when it crosses a trust boundary, involves an internet-facing asset, or is not protected by a VPN.
insecure-communication-over-internet.riskAssessment: The impact is determined by the highest Confidentiality and Integrity requirements of the data assets transmitted over the link.
insecure-communication-over-internet.falsePositives: A risk might be a false positive if the communication occurs over a completely isolated and physically secured network segment where interception is considered impossible.

malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.title: Malicious Browser Components from Untrusted Sources (BSI SYS.1.2.1)
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.description: If web browsers, plug-ins, or extensions are obtained from untrusted sources, malicious functions can be executed unintentionally and unnoticed.
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.impact: Compromise of client systems through malicious browser components can lead to phishing, unauthorized data access and exfiltration (breach of confidentiality),
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein SYS.1.2.1 (Allgemeiner Client). The described threat aligns with fundamental secure configuration principles.
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.action: Enforce Secure Software Sourcing and Client Hardening
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.mitigation: Only obtain browsers, plugins, and extensions from trusted, official sources (e.g., official vendor websites, corporate software portals).
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.check: Are there effective technical controls and policies that prevent users from installing software from untrusted sources? Is there a central, vetted software repository for users? Are client systems regularly scanned for unauthorized software?
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.detectionLogic: This risk applies to any client-side technical asset used by a human to interact with the internet or other systems. The rule identifies assets configured as human-operated clients (e.g., browsers, desktops) which, without proper controls, are susceptible to this threat.
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered high in environments without strict controls on software installation. The impact is directly related to the sensitivity of the data accessed or processed by the user via the compromised client. Accessing mission-critical systems with a compromised browser results in a very high impact.
malicious-browser-components-from-untrus.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive in environments where, despite the technical possibility, strong organizational policies and user training effectively prevent the installation of untrusted software. Verifying the effectiveness of such non-technical controls is required to dismiss the risk.

insecure-browser-configuration.title: Insecure Web Browser Configuration (BSI APP.3.2)
insecure-browser-configuration.description: If web browsers are configured insecurely, confidential data can be accidentally or maliciously exposed to unauthorized third parties. Passwords can also be unintentionally shared. If cookies, passwords, history, form data, and search queries are stored, or unnecessary extensions are enabled, data can be more easily read and misused by third parties or malware.
insecure-browser-configuration.impact: This can lead to the theft of credentials, session hijacking, disclosure of sensitive personal or business data, and unauthorized access to other systems, compromising the confidentiality and integrity of information.
insecure-browser-configuration.mitigation: Enforce a secure baseline configuration for all browsers used to access corporate resources. This includes disabling password saving, clearing history/cookies on exit, restricting or auditing browser extensions, and using privacy-enhancing features. Use Mobile Device Management (MDM) or Group Policies (GPO) to enforce these settings. Educate users on the risks of insecure browser settings and extensions.
insecure-browser-configuration.check: Are there centrally managed, enforced security policies for web browsers? Is password saving disabled in the browser? Is the installation of unapproved extensions blocked or monitored? Are users trained on secure browser usage?
insecure-browser-configuration.detectionLogic: Triggers for any client-type technical assets (e.g., Browser, Desktop, Mobile App) that communicate with other assets handling sensitive data (rated
insecure-browser-configuration.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered higher for clients that are external or directly exposed to the internet, as they are less likely to be under strict corporate control. The impact is determined by the maximum confidentiality and integrity ratings of the assets the client connects to. Accessing a
insecure-browser-configuration.falsePositives: This risk can be considered a false positive if endpoint security measures (like browser isolation/virtualization) are in place but n@SystemType:OT modeled, or if the client asset is used in a context (e.g., public kiosk) where it never accesses sensitive systems or data.

unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.title: Unintentional Data Leakage on Mobile End-Device (BSI APP.4.4)
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.description: Data is transferred to and from a mobile application through various channels provided by the mobile operating system.
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.impact: If sensitive data is not properly protected on the mobile device, it can be exfiltrated by other malicious applications,
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz APP.4.4.A5 (Protection of local data). Also relates to OWASP MASVS V2 (Data Storage and Privacy Requirements).
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.action: Implement Secure Data Handling and Storage on Mobile Devices
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.mitigation: Sensitive data should not be stored on the mobile device unless absolutely necessary. If storage is required, use platform-provided secure,
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.check: Is sensitive data stored locally on the device? If so, is it encrypted using platform-provided secure storage mechanisms?
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.detectionLogic: This risk is triggered for all in-scope technical assets of type
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.riskAssessment: The likelihood and impact of this risk are determined by the highest confidentiality level of the data processed or stored by the mobile application.
unintentional-data-leakage-on-mobile-dev.falsePositives: This risk is raised based on the potential for data leakage. A model cannot verify the implementation details of specific controls like disabled clipboard access

inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.title: Inadequate Monitoring of Network Boundaries (BSI DER.1.A4)
inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.description: If no detection systems are used and the detection functions available in IT systems and applications are not used, attackers can more easily penetrate the institution
inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.impact: Successful exploitation can lead to undetected attackers persisting in the network, accessing or exfiltrating sensitive data, and potentially escalating privileges to compromise further systems. This directly threatens the confidentiality and integrity of information.
inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz DER.1.A4 Use of systems for attack detection (IDS)
inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.mitigation: Deploy IDS/IPS solutions to monitor traffic at critical network boundaries, especially where trust levels change.
inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.check: Are network communications, especially those crossing trust boundaries, monitored by an IDS/IPS? Are alerts from these systems reviewed and acted upon? Are logs from relevant assets collected and analyzed?
inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.detectionLogic: This rule triggers for all communication links that cross a trust boundary.
inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.riskAssessment: The likelihood of an undetected intrusion is considered very likely for unmonitored network boundary crossings.
inadequate-monitoring-of-network-boundar.falsePositives: Can occur if monitoring solutions (e.g., host-based or agent-based IDS) are not represented in the threat model.

insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.title: Insufficient Personnel for Log Analysis and Monitoring (related to BSI ORP.4)
insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.description: If there is not enough personnel to evaluate log data, security-relevant events cannot be fully detected. This can lead to attacks remaining hidden for extended periods or only being discovered after significant damage, such as data exfiltration, has already occurred.
insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.impact: A failure to detect security incidents in a timely manner can compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of critical systems and data. It may allow attackers prolonged unauthorized access, leading to severe data breaches, system disruption, and a delayed incident response, which magnifies the overall business impact.
insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz ORP.4: Detection of Security-Relevant Events, specifically Requirement ORP.4.A5 (Personnel resources for the detection of security-relevant events).
insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.action: Ensure Sufficient Staffing for Security Monitoring and Analysis
insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.mitigation: Allocate adequate and qualified personnel for the regular analysis of log data and the evaluation of security-relevant events. Establish clear processes and responsibilities for monitoring activities, including reviewing logs from critical assets. Utilize security automation and tooling (e.g., SIEM) to support the security team and ensure that alerts are managed effectively. Also, maintain a process for evaluating external threat intelligence to proactively identify vulnerabilities.
insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.check: Are there dedicated personnel or a team (e.g., a SOC) responsible for security monitoring? Is there a defined and followed process for log review? Is the workload for security analysis considered manageable for the current staff? Is there tooling in place to aggregate and analyze logs from critical systems?
insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.detectionLogic: This organizational risk is raised for critical, in-scope technical assets that are not client-side technologies. The assumption is that these assets produce valuable log data that requires monitoring. The risk is heightened for assets with high confidentiality, integrity, or availability requirements, as the impact of an undetected incident would be greater. Monitoring and security control platforms themselves are excluded.
insufficient-personnel-for-log-analysis-.falsePositives: This risk is organizational and cannot be fully verified by the technical model alone. The organization may have a well-staffed 24/7 SOC and robust monitoring processes, which would render this risk a false positive. Confirmation requires discussion with the operations and security teams about their monitoring capabilities and resources.

inadequate-incident-handling-con1.title: Inadequate Handling of Security Incidents (BSI CON.1)
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.description: In practice, security incidents can never be completely ruled out, even with many security measures in place.
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.impact: Without a proper procedure for handling security incidents, wrong decisions can be made under pressure.
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein CON.1 (Security Incident Management). Specifically relates to requirements like CON.1.A4 (Preparation for handling security incidents) and CON.1.A5 (Reporting and handling security incidents).
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.action: Establish and Maintain a Formal Incident Response Process
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.mitigation: Define and implement a comprehensive incident response plan. This includes clear procedures for detection, reporting, analysis, containment, eradication, and recovery.
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.check: Is there a documented incident response plan? Are roles and responsibilities for incident handling clearly defined?
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.detectionLogic: This is an organizational risk. The model identifies technical assets where effective and timely incident response is most critical.
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.riskAssessment: Likelihood is HIGH if no formal incident response plan exists or is tested. Likelihood is MEDIUM if a plan exists but is not well-communicated or regularly practiced.
inadequate-incident-handling-con1.falsePositives: This risk is organizational. The model can only identify assets where incident response is *critical*.

improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.title: Improper Incident Handling and Evidence Destruction (BSI DER.2)
improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.description: If personnel react improperly or fail to follow established procedures after a security incident,
improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.impact: The primary impact is the loss of forensic evidence, which prevents a proper investigation into the incident
improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein DER.2 (Security Incident Management).
improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.action: Establish and Train Formal Incident Response Procedures with Evidence Preservation.
improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.mitigation: Develop a formal, documented incident response plan that includes clear procedures for evidence preservation (e.g., isolating systems instead of shutting them down, creating forensic images of disks and memory before performing remediation).
improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.check: Is there a formal incident response plan? Does it include specific steps for evidence preservation? Are IT and security personnel trained on this plan? Are roles and responsibilities for incident handling clearly defined?
improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.detectionLogic: This is an organizational risk that applies to critical systems where an incident would require a formal response.
improper-incident-handling-and-evidence-.falsePositives: This risk is inherently organizational. An organization might have excellent incident response procedures in place that are not visible in the threat model.

improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.title: Improper Handling of Personal Data during IT Forensic Investigations (BSI-Style)
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.description: During IT forensic investigations, it is common to copy, secure, and analyze all data deemed necessary. This data frequently includes personal data of employees, partners, or customers. If this data is accessed without a valid legal basis or without the involvement of the Data Protection Officer (DPO), the institution may violate legal regulations (e.g., @DataType:PII
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.impact: Violating data protection laws and internal policies can lead to significant legal fines, reputational damage, and loss of trust. Improper access to personal data compromises its confidentiality and can disrupt business processes if forensic activities are challenged or halted due to non-compliance.
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz principles in DER.1 (Data Protection) and CON.8 (Handling of security incidents). Forensic processes must adhere to fundamental data protection principles like purpose limitation, data minimization, and lawful processing.
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.action: Establish and Enforce Data Handling Procedures for Forensic Investigations
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.mitigation: Define and document clear procedures for all IT forensic investigations. These procedures must:
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.check: Are there documented, formally approved procedures for conducting IT forensic investigations? Do these procedures explicitly address the handling of personal data and mandate the involvement of the DPO? Are access controls for forensic evidence stores implemented and audited?
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for any technical assets identified as part of the forens@SystemType:ICS workflow (tagged with `@forens@SystemType:ICS-tool` or `@forensic-datastore`) that process or store sensitive data (Confidentiality of
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.riskAssessment: The likelihood of this risk is considered
improper-handling-of-@DataType:PII-durin.falsePositives: This risk may be a false positive if robust, audited, and enforced procedures for handling personal data during forens@SystemType:ICS are already in place. The technical model alone cannot verify the existence or effectiveness of such organizational controls.

improper-evidence-handling-bsi.title: Improper Handling and Securing of Digital Evidence (BSI-based)
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.description: If digital evidence is secured incorrectly or not quickly enough, important data can be lost that cannot be recovered later.
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.impact: The loss or corruption of digital evidence compromises the integrity of post-incident investigations.
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein DER.4 (Incident Management), specifically requirement DER.4.A19 (Forensic analysis of IT systems).
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.action: Establish and Regularly Practice Forensic Readiness and Evidence Handling Procedures
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.mitigation: Develop and document clear, step-by-step procedures for evidence collection, including the preservation of volatile data (e.g., memory, network state) and non-volatile data (e.g., disk images).
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.check: Are there documented procedures for digital evidence collection? Are personnel trained on these procedures and the use of forensic tools? Are drills conducted to test forensic readiness?
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.detectionLogic: This organizational risk is raised against technical assets that are critical for security and incident analysis.
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered high for critical systems if no explicit forensic readiness measures are in place, as mistakes are common under the pressure of a real incident.
improper-evidence-handling-bsi.falsePositives: This risk is procedural and organizational. The model identifies assets where this weakness would have the greatest impact.

apt-firmware-persistence.title: APT Persistence via Firmware/Hardware Manipulation
apt-firmware-persistence.description: Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) aim for long-term infiltration of target networks. A sophisticated technique is to install persistent backdoors by manipulating low-level, hardware-near components like system firmware (e.g., UEFI/BIOS). Such modifications are extremely difficult to detect and can survive traditional incident response measures like reinstalling the operating system or replacing hard drives. The BSI warns that attackers might even compromise firmware update routines, ensuring their malicious code persists even after a legitimate update is applied. This grants the attacker a permanent, stealthy foothold inside the IT infrastructure.
apt-firmware-persistence.impact: Successful exploitation results in a complete and persistent compromise of the affected asset
apt-firmware-persistence.asvs: This advanced threat exceeds the scope of most standard ASVS checks. However, it relates to the principles of system integrity verification, such as in section V14. Related NIST guidelines like SP 800-193 (Platform Firmware Resiliency) are highly relevant.
apt-firmware-persistence.action: Implement Hardware and Firmware Integrity Verification and Control
apt-firmware-persistence.mitigation: For critical assets, implement a defense-in-depth strategy for hardware security. Use platforms with a hardware-based root of trust (e.g., TPM). Enforce Secure Boot to ensure only signed and trusted firmware, bootloaders, and operating systems can execute. Where possible, use remote attestation to continuously verify the integrity of platforms before granting them access to sensitive parts of the network. Maintain a secure supply chain for hardware procurement to prevent tampering before deployment.
apt-firmware-persistence.check: Are critical systems equipped with TPMs? Is Secure Boot enabled and actively enforced? Is there a process for remote attestation to verify platform integrity? Is the hardware supply chain managed and trusted?
apt-firmware-persistence.detectionLogic: This rule triggers on high-value technical assets that are attractive targets for APTs. The risk is raised for assets that are either explicitly tagged as high-value targets or are internet-facing systems processing or storing sensitive data. The risk is considered for physical, virtual, and containerized machines, as they all rely on underlying host firmware.
apt-firmware-persistence.riskAssessment: The impact of such a compromise is always considered
apt-firmware-persistence.falsePositives: A risk might be flagged on an asset where this attack vector is deemed non-viable. This can be considered a false positive if the organization can demonstrate robust and actively monitored hardware-level security controls (e.g., strictly enforced Secure Boot, remote attestation) that effectively mitigate this specific threat.

destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.title: Destruction of Forensic Evidence after an APT Incident (BSI CON.3)
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.description: After an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) incident, IT systems are often reinstalled or decommissioned to remove the threat.
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.impact: Destroying forensic evidence prevents a thorough analysis of the security incident. This can make it impossible to determine the full scope of the compromise,
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz CON.3 Security Incident Management, specifically CON.3.A15 Forensic investigations.
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.action: Establish and Adhere to a Forensic-Ready Incident Response Plan
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.mitigation: A formal incident response plan must be in place that explicitly mandates the creation of forensic images (disk and memory) of affected systems *before* any recovery or re-installation procedures begin.
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.check: Is there a documented incident response plan? Does the plan explicitly require forensic imaging before system recovery?
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.detectionLogic: This organizational risk is raised for all in-scope technical assets that are client systems or external entities.
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.riskAssessment: The likelihood of this risk materializing during a real incident is considered
destruction-of-forensic-evidence-after-a.falsePositives: This risk is procedural and organizational. A model cannot verify the existence or quality of an incident response plan.

apt-premature-cleanup-detection.title: Premature Detection of APT Remediation (BSI-OPS.1.2.5)
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.description: During the response to an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT), attackers who are still active within the infrastructure might detect the analysis and cleanup activities.
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.impact: If attackers detect the remediation efforts, they can actively work to undermine them. This can lead to a failed cleanup, prolonged attacker presence, installation of deeper and more resilient backdoors, destruction of evidence, and intentional sabotage of critical systems. The result is a more severe and costly incident, potentially compromising the integrity, availability, and confidentiality of the entire IT infrastructure.
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein OPS.1.2.5 (Incident Handling). This risk describes a specific threat during the remediation phase of an APT incident, where attackers detect the cleanup activities.
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.action: Establish and Use Secure Out-of-Band (OOB) Channels for Incident Response
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.mitigation: All communication and coordination for responding to critical incidents like APTs MUST be conducted over a separate, trusted infrastructure (OOB channel) that is isolated from the compromised network. Remediation activities should be planned as a coordinated, simultaneous operation to prevent tipping off the attacker. Tag communication links used for this purpose in the model with `@out-of-band-management` to signify they use a secure OOB channel.
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.check: Is there a documented incident response plan that mandates OOB channels for high-impact incidents? Are technical assets used for these channels modeled and isolated? Are remediation plans designed for simultaneous, coordinated execution?
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.detectionLogic: This rule identifies administrative or DevOps-related communication links (`usage: devops`) that are explicitly marked as using an out-of-band channel via the `@out-of-band-management` tag. The assumption is that using the standard, potentially compromised network for incident response or high-privilege administration on critical assets risks detection by a resident APT.
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.riskAssessment: The likelihood is high if administrative tasks are performed
apt-premature-cleanup-detection.falsePositives: An out-of-band channel might exist in reality but is not documented in the Threagile model with the `@out-of-band-management` tag. This risk should be confirmed with the operations and security teams.

service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.title: Service Disruption During APT Incident Cleanup (BSI Scenario)
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.description: During the cleanup of an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) incident, various IT systems may need to be reinstalled and networks temporarily isolated. This necessary remediation can lead to the failure of IT systems and services, making them limited or completely unavailable.
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.impact: If the cleanup process is prolonged, especially due to a lack of sufficient or accessible documentation for rebuilding, it can severely impact the institution
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein CON.4 (Incident Response), specifically CON.4.A7 (Handling security incidents), and OPS.1.1.5 (Standard operating procedures), which covers the need for recovery documentation.
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.action: Develop and Maintain a Comprehensive Incident Response and Business Continuity Plan
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.mitigation: Establish a robust incident response plan that includes procedures for isolating and remediating compromised systems after an APT. Crucially, maintain up-to-date and accessible documentation for all critical systems to enable rapid and predictable rebuilding (e.g., Infrastructure as Code, configuration backups, detailed runbooks). Regularly test the recovery procedures through drills and simulations to minimize downtime and ensure business continuity. Implementing redundancy for critical components can prevent a total service outage during remediation.
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.check: Is there a documented incident response plan for major threats like APTs? Is system documentation for recovery complete, current, and readily available? Are recovery procedures regularly tested? Are critical systems designed with redundancy?
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.detectionLogic: This risk is triggered for in-scope technical assets with high-availability requirements that lack redundancy. The assumption is that such assets represent single points of failure, and their remediation after an APT incident would cause a significant service outage, as described in the BSI scenario.
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.riskAssessment: Likelihood is based on the probability of a successful APT attack requiring major cleanup, which can be considered
service-disruption-during-apt-cleanup.falsePositives: The model cannot verify the quality of an organization

apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.title: APT Lateral Movement and Persistence (based on BSI Threat Scenario)
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.description: In an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) attack, attackers gain detailed knowledge of the target environment
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.impact: If an attacker establishes a foothold on a critical system, they can leverage it to compromise other connected systems. This can lead to widespread data exfiltration, manipulation of critical business processes, persistent long-term access, and significant disruption. The ability to move laterally multiplies the potential damage from a single initial breach.
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.asvs: Derived from BSI threat descriptions for Advanced Persistent Threats. Related concepts include BSI Bausteine DER.1 (Detection) and OPS.1.1.5 (Handling security incidents).
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.action: Implement and Enforce Strong Network Segmentation, Access Control, and Threat Detection
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.mitigation: Employ a defense-in-depth strategy. Use micro-segmentation to isolate critical systems and restrict east-west traffic. Apply the principle of least privilege to all service and user accounts. Enforce strong, multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all administrative access and critical service-to-service communication. Implement robust logging and monitoring across the infrastructure, using Network and Endpoint Detection and Response (NDR/EDR) solutions to detect anomalous behavior indicative of lateral movement. Use egress filtering to prevent data exfiltration.
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.check: Are internal network segments and trust boundaries properly isolated? Is traffic between critical systems monitored for anomalies? Is access based on the principle of least privilege? Is strong authentication required for administrative and service-to-service communication?
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.detectionLogic: This rule identifies high-value technical assets (high RAA, critical CIA ratings). It then checks for outgoing communication links to other high-value assets, which could serve as pathways for lateral movement. The risk is elevated if these pathways exist, especially across trust boundaries or with weak authentication, as they represent how an APT might expand their control after an initial compromise.
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.riskAssessment: The impact is determined by the sensitivity of the initial asset and the most critical asset it can reach. A high-value asset that can communicate with many other critical systems presents a very high impact. The likelihood is based on the number of potential lateral movement paths and the strength of the controls on those paths (e.g., authentication). An environment with many unrestricted pathways from one critical system to another is considered more likely to be exploited for lateral movement.
apt-lateral-movement-and-persistence.falsePositives: The model may flag legitimate and necessary communication between critical systems. This risk requires a qualitative assessment to confirm if the existing monitoring, authentication, and access control measures for these connections are sufficient to mitigate the threat of lateral movement.

un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.title: Security Measures Temporarily Disabled but Not Re-Enabled
un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.description: The overall security level of an application or system depends on all security measures being implemented completely and correctly.
un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.impact: If security controls are not re-enabled, the system operates at a lower security level than designed.
un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.action: Establish and Enforce Secure Configuration and Change Management Processes
un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.mitigation: Establish strict change management procedures that include checklists for disabling and re-enabling security functions.
un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.check: Are there documented procedures for temporarily disabling and re-enabling security controls? Is there an automated system to verify the security configuration baseline against a golden image? Are alerts generated for disabled security controls?
un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.detectionLogic: This risk is common on systems that are manually configured or undergo frequent manual changes during deployment or maintenance.
un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered higher for systems requiring manual intervention during deployment or updates. The impact is directly related to the
un-restarted-temporarily-disabled-securi.falsePositives: This risk might be flagged for assets even if the organization has very mature, checklist-driven, or automated operational procedures that prevent this from happening.

ineffective-or-uneconomical-security-mea.title: Ineffective or Uneconomical Security Measures
ineffective-or-uneconomical-security-mea.description: When security measures are implemented without considering practical aspects of their use, they might be ineffective or uneconomical.
ineffective-or-uneconomical-security-mea.impact: If security controls can be bypassed or are misapplied, assets they are meant to protect are exposed to threats, potentially leading to the compromise of their confidentiality, integrity, or availability. This can result in data breaches, system takeovers, and other security incidents despite the presence of security measures, creating a false sense of security.

ineffective-or-uneconomical-security-mea.mitigation: Ensure that all access paths to a sensitive asset are protected with a consistent and appropriate level of security.

It identifies sensitive technical assets that have at least one strongly authenticated incoming communication link but also at least one weak (unauthenticated) remote communication link. This constellation suggests a potential bypass of the intended security controls.
ineffective-or-uneconomical-security-mea.riskAssessment: The impact is determined by the CIA requirements of the asset being protected. A higher-value asset leads to a higher impact. The likelihood is considered high because the weak access path is readily available for exploitation. The risk is raised for each weak

This requires manual verification. However, unauthenticated access to sensitive systems is generally discouraged.

lack-of-independent-isms-review.title: Lack of Independent ISMS Review
lack-of-independent-isms-review.description: In many institutions, the Information Security Officer (ISO) is responsible for verifying the implementation of security measures.
lack-of-independent-isms-review.impact: If the ISMS is not independently and effectively audited, the overall security level of the institution can be significantly degraded.
lack-of-independent-isms-review.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Kompendium, Baustein ORP.3
lack-of-independent-isms-review.action: Establish and Execute a Regular, Independent ISMS Audit Program
lack-of-independent-isms-review.mitigation: Implement a formal process for regularly auditing the ISMS. These audits must be performed by a party independent of the Information Security Officer
lack-of-independent-isms-review.check: Is there a documented process for auditing the ISMS? Are audits performed by a party independent of the ISO? Is there a recent audit report available? Are findings tracked to resolution?
lack-of-independent-isms-review.detectionLogic: This is an organizational risk related to governance and process assurance. In a technical model, this risk is surfaced by attaching it to assets that are central to security management.
lack-of-independent-isms-review.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered HIGH if there is no established independent audit process for the ISMS. The impact is determined by the highest sensitivity of the assets and data managed under the ISMS, as a process failure at this level puts all protected assets at risk. The risk is calculated based on the CIA rating of the specific technical asset it is attached to in the model.
lack-of-independent-isms-review.falsePositives: This risk is inherently organizational and cannot be validated from a technical model alone. The model surfaces the risk based on the presence of a security management role.

lack-of-central-audit-planning-orp2-a1.title: Lack of Central and Long-Term Audit Planning (BSI ORP.2.A1)
lack-of-central-audit-planning-orp2-a1.description: If audits and reviews are not planned centrally and for the long term, it can lead to an imbalanced audit scope.

lack-of-central-audit-planning-orp2-a1.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein ORP.2 (Information security auditing and review), Requirement ORP.2.A1 (Planning of information security audits).

insufficient-audit-planning-orp3-g6.title: Insufficient Audit Planning (BSI ORP.3.G6)
insufficient-audit-planning-orp3-g6.description: If an audit or security check is poorly planned and not sufficiently coordinated with the institution, required personnel may not be available during the review.
insufficient-audit-planning-orp3-g6.impact: The primary impact is that existing security vulnerabilities, configuration errors, or non-compliance with security policies may go undetected.
insufficient-audit-planning-orp3-g6.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein ORP.3 (Security check and audit), Requirement ORP.3.A1 (Planning security checks).

insufficient-audit-planning-orp3-g6.check: Is there a documented procedure for planning audits and security checks? Are audit plans created, documented, and communicated in advance?

insufficient-audit-planning-orp3-g6.falsePositives: This risk is organizational and cannot be fully verified by the technical model alone. An organization might have a robust audit planning process.

insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.title: Insufficient Compliance with Co-determination Law during Audits
insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.description: Data from audits and revisions can inadvertently contain information that allows for conclusions about employee performance.
insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.impact: Violating co-determination laws can lead to legal disputes, fines, and a significant loss of trust between employees and management.
insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.asvs: Derived from user-provided BSI-style text. The principles align with BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein DER.1 Data Protection, specifically requirements like DER.1.A6
insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.action: Establish Clear Policies for Audit Data Usage
insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.mitigation: Clearly define and document the purpose of all auditing and logging activities, explicitly excluding employee performance evaluation.
insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.check: Is there a written policy governing the use of audit and log data? Has the employee representation body formally approved this policy? Are access logs for audit data reviewed to prevent misuse?
insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.detectionLogic: This organizational risk is raised for technical assets that typically collect detailed, user-specific logs which could be repurposed for performance monitoring.
insufficient-compliance-with-co-determin.falsePositives: This risk can only be confirmed by reviewing internal company policies and legal agreements with the employee representation body. A technical model cannot verify the existence or enforcement of such policies.

concealment-of-security-weaknesses-con1-.title: Concealment of Security Weaknesses (BSI CON.1.A23)
concealment-of-security-weaknesses-con1-.description: Employees, fearing that their mistakes will be discovered during audits, reviews, or testing, may attempt to conceal existing security problems or vulnerabilities. This can lead to a distorted and overly optimistic view of the actual security posture, leaving critical vulnerabilities unaddressed.
concealment-of-security-weaknesses-con1-.impact: Concealing vulnerabilities means they remain unaddressed and unmitigated, providing attackers with a persistent window of opportunity. The resulting false sense of security can lead to misinformed risk management decisions. Ultimately, this can result in severe security incidents, compromising the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of the system and associated data.

failure-to-implement-up-bund-2017.title: Failure to Implement UP Bund 2017 Requirements
failure-to-implement-up-bund-2017.impact: Non-compliance with UP Bund 2017 can lead to significant legal, contractual, and financial penalties. It indicates a fundamental gap in the security governance, suggesting that required security controls (as defined by IT-Grundschutz) may be missing, unenforced, or unverified. This elevates the overall risk of security incidents, which could compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of all information assets within the system

failure-to-implement-up-bund-2017.mitigation: Implement a comprehensive ISMS that fully aligns with the requirements of BSI IT-Grundschutz. This includes defining security policies, assigning responsibilities, implementing technical and organizational controls, and creating incident response plans. Crucially, conduct regular internal and external security audits based on the BSI
failure-to-implement-up-bund-2017.check: Is the organization obligated to comply with UP Bund 2017? Is a formal ISMS based on IT-Grundschutz established and actively maintained? Are regular IS audits, as required by the plan, being conducted and their results acted upon? Can compliance be demonstrated through documentation and audit reports?

concealment-of-security-deficiencies-dur.title: Concealment of Security Deficiencies during Audits (BSI-based)
concealment-of-security-deficiencies-dur.description: Personnel might fear that an information security audit will reveal their mistakes. To avoid repercussions, they might conceal or downplay existing security problems, presenting a false picture of the actual security posture. This prevents the discovery and correction of security vulnerabilities.
concealment-of-security-deficiencies-dur.impact: When security deficiencies are intentionally hidden, they remain uncorrected and can be exploited by attackers. Furthermore, management might misjudge the true risk level associated with a system, leading to poor security investment decisions and a false sense of security. This undermines the entire governance and audit process.

concealment-of-security-deficiencies-dur.mitigation: Promote a security culture where reporting issues is encouraged and not punished. leakage-of-is-audit-information.description: During an information security audit, sensitive data such as identified vulnerabilities, security gaps, and potential attack vectors are collected and documented.

disabled-security-controls-reenabled.description: The security level of an institution is influenced by whether security measures are implemented completely and correctly.

disabled-security-controls-reenabled.falsePositives: This risk may be flagged for assets within a well-managed CI/CD pipeline where automated post-deployment checks already mitigate this process failure.

impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.title: Impractical or Ineffective Security Measures (BSI-style)
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.description: If security measures are implemented without taking practical aspects into account, these measures may be ineffective. For example, it is pointless to block an entrance area with turnstiles if employees can enter the building through an open side entrance instead. It can also happen that individual measures are taken that do not make economic sense. For example, for the protection of information with a normal need for protection with regard to confidentiality, an appropriately implemented rights and roles concept is more sensible and economical than setting up complex, certificate-based encryption on the file server.
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.impact: Ineffective measures create a false sense of security while leaving critical vulnerabilities open. This can result in security controls being bypassed, leading to unauthorized access, data breaches (loss of Confidentiality), data manipulation (loss of Integrity), or service disruption (loss of Availability). Over-engineered controls can increase complexity and cost without providing proportional security benefits.
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz principles. Aligns with OWASP Top 10 2021: A04 - Insecure Design.
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.action: Review and Refine Security Architecture and Control Selection
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.mitigation: Ensure security controls are placed appropriately within the data flow to be effective. For internet-facing systems, sensitive backend components should not be directly exposed. Instead, traffic should be routed through dedicated entry-point components like Reverse Proxies, WAFs, or API Gateways. Regularly review the architecture to identify and eliminate bypass routes. For data protection, select controls (like encryption) that are appropriate for the data
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.check: Are there direct communication paths from untrusted networks (like the internet) to sensitive backend services, bypassing intended security controls (like WAFs, proxies)? Are the implemented security measures, such as encryption levels, proportional to the protection requirements of the assets?
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.detectionLogic: This rule identifies two potential architectural flaws: 1. A
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.riskAssessment: For bypassed controls, the likelihood is high if a direct, unfiltered path exists, and the impact is based on the CIA requirements of the target asset. For over-engineered controls, the risk is typically lower and relates more to operational complexity and cost, but can still indicate a misunderstanding of security requirements.
impractical-or-ineffective-security-meas.falsePositives: A direct connection might be intentionally designed and secured through other means (e.g., strong endpoint security, specific protocol hardening). A strong encryption choice might be a preemptive measure or required by a blanket policy. Manual verification is required.

lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.title: Lack of Impartial ISMS Audit (BSI ORP.4)
lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.description: In many organizations, the Information Security Officer (ISO) is responsible for verifying the implementation of security measures.
lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.impact: If the ISMS is not reviewed by an impartial entity, significant weaknesses in security governance, processes, and controls may go undetected.
lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Kompendium 2023, Baustein ORP.4 (Internal and external audit), specifically Requirement ORP.4.A6 (Performing internal audits), which emphasizes the need for auditor objectivity and impartiality.
lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.action: Establish an Independent Audit Function for the ISMS
lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.mitigation: Ensure that the ISMS is regularly audited by personnel who are independent of the ISMS management function (i.e., not the ISO).
lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.check: Is there a documented process for auditing the ISMS? Is the entity (person or team) performing the ISMS audit demonstrably independent from the ISO and their team?
lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.detectionLogic: This organizational risk is detected by checking for the presence of an Information Security Officer (
lack-of-impartial-isms-audit.falsePositives: A false positive may occur if the audit function is performed by an external party not documented in the threat model, or if an internal asset performs audits but is not tagged with the

inadequate-auditor-qualification-and-pre.title: Inadequate Auditor Qualification and Preparation (BSI DER.2)
inadequate-auditor-qualification-and-pre.impact: Flawed audit findings can result in a false sense of security, where critical vulnerabilities remain unaddressed.
inadequate-auditor-qualification-and-pre.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Kompendium: Baustein DER.2
inadequate-auditor-qualification-and-pre.action: Establish and Enforce a Formal Process for Auditor Selection and Audit Preparation
inadequate-auditor-qualification-and-pre.mitigation: Define clear, stringent qualification criteria for both internal and external auditors based on the scope and complexity of the systems being audited.
inadequate-auditor-qualification-and-pre.check: Is there a formal policy for selecting IS auditors? Are qualification criteria documented and enforced?
inadequate-auditor-qualification-and-pre.detectionLogic: This is an organizational risk related to the audit process. It can be raised against technical assets that are typically subject to or involved in security audits.
inadequate-auditor-qualification-and-pre.falsePositives: This risk is organizational and cannot be fully confirmed by the technical model alone.

lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.title: Lack of Central and Long-Term Audit Planning (BSI REV.1.A4)
lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.description: If information security audits/revisions are not planned centrally and for the long term, some organizational units or systems might be audited frequently while others are not audited at all. Also, changes to the ISMS (Information Security Management System) might not be adequately examined if audits are irregular. This makes it very difficult or impossible to properly assess the security posture of the entire information system.
lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.impact: Unaudited areas may harbor undetected vulnerabilities, and security controls for new or changed components may not be verified. This leads to an increased risk of security incidents, non-compliance with regulations, and potential data breaches, as the actual security state of the system cannot be reliably determined.
lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz Kompendium 2023: Baustein REV.1 Revision, Anforderung REV.1.A4 Planung der IS-Revision.
lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.action: Establish a Centralized and Regular Audit Program
lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.mitigation: Develop and implement a formal, long-term audit plan that is managed centrally. The plan should define the scope, frequency, and methodology for audits across all organizational units and information systems. It must ensure regular coverage of all critical areas and include provisions for ad-hoc audits in response to significant changes or security incidents. The audit plan should be approved by management and communicated to relevant stakeholders.
lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.check: Is there a formal, documented information security audit plan? Is it managed centrally? Does it specify scope and frequency for all critical systems? Is there a process for auditing significant changes to the system?
lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.detectionLogic: This is a fundamental organizational risk that applies to the entire modeled system. The risk is generated if the model contains at least one in-scope, high-value technical asset, as the absence of a structured audit process poses a significant threat to such assets. The risk is raised once for the entire system, with its impact scaled by the highest criticality asset found.
lack-of-central-audit-planning-rev1.a4.falsePositives: This risk is organizational and cannot be validated purely from a technical model. The organization may have a robust audit program that is not represented in the model. Verification requires checking for an official, management-approved audit plan and schedule.

inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.title: Inadequate IS Audit Planning (BSI ORP.3.A1)
inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.description: If an Information Security (IS) audit is poorly planned and not properly coordinated with the responsible personnel, the required subject matter experts may not be available during the on-site inspection.
inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.impact: A poorly planned or executed audit provides a false sense of security. Undiscovered vulnerabilities or compliance gaps can be exploited later,
inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein ORP.3 IS-Revision, Requirement ORP.3.A1 Planung der IS-Revision (Planning of the IS audit).
inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.action: Establish and Follow a Formal IS Audit Planning and Coordination Process
inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.mitigation: Define and enforce a formal process for planning and conducting IS audits. This process must include proactive coordination with all relevant stakeholders to ensure personnel availability and access to necessary systems, evidence, and documentation.
inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.check: Is there a documented process for IS audit planning? Are audit schedules consistently coordinated with the affected departments and personnel?
inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.detectionLogic: This is an organizational risk that applies to any system requiring security assurance. In a technical model, this risk is raised for any in-scope assets that are highly sensitive (and thus require thorough auditing)
inadequate-is-audit-planning-orp3-a1.falsePositives: This risk is procedural and organizational; its existence cannot be confirmed by a technical model alone. The organization may have a robust audit planning process that is not reflected in the model.

is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..title: IS Audit as Performance Monitoring without Staff Council Involvement (BSI DER.3.A1)
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..description: During IS audits, aspects can be checked that could allow conclusions to be drawn about how personnel behave at work and how capable they are.
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..impact: Failure to involve the staff council when an audit could be perceived as performance monitoring can lead to the delay or cancellation of crucial security audits.
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Kompendium 2023, Baustein DER.3 Revision, Requirement DER.3.A1 Einbindung der Personalvertretung (Involvement of the staff council).
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..action: Ensure Staff Council Involvement in IS Audits
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..mitigation: Establish and follow a formal process for planning IS audits that includes the timely and appropriate involvement of the staff council, especially when employee performance or behavior data might be collected or analyzed.
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..check: Is there a documented process for involving the staff council in IS audit planning? Is the staff council regularly consulted before audits that could involve employee data are conducted? Is there evidence (e.g., meeting minutes, official agreements) of this involvement?
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..detectionLogic: This is an organizational risk that applies to technical assets used for auditing and monitoring purposes.
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered high if a formal process for involving the staff council is missing or not followed.
is-audit-as-performance-monitoring-der3..falsePositives: This risk is inherently organizational. A technical model cannot definitively know if the staff council was involved.

personnel-failure-knowledge-monopoly.title: Personnel Failure / Knowledge Monopoly (BSI ORP.4.A23)
personnel-failure-knowledge-monopoly.description: The failure or absence of key personnel can prevent an organization from performing its core tasks and business processes.
personnel-failure-knowledge-monopoly.impact: If a non-redundant, critical system can no longer be operated due to personnel failure, its availability is directly compromised.
personnel-failure-knowledge-monopoly.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz ORP.4: Notfallmanagement (Contingency Management), Requirement ORP.4.A23: Regelungen für den Personalausfall (Regulations for personnel failure).
personnel-failure-knowledge-monopoly.action: Implement Redundancy, Knowledge Transfer, and Contingency Planning
personnel-failure-knowledge-monopoly.mitigation: Ensure that no single person is the only one capable of operating or maintaining a critical system.
personnel-failure-knowledge-monopoly.check: Is the technical asset marked as redundant in the model? Is there a documented and tested contingency plan for this asset/service?

component-failure-endangering-availabili.description: If components of an IT system fail, for example due to defective hardware or a power outage, the entire IT operation can be disrupted.
component-failure-endangering-availabili.impact: A failure of a critical, non-redundant component leads to a denial of service, directly impacting the availability of the technical asset,
component-failure-endangering-availabili.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein CON.1 (Redundant IT Systems) and INF.5 (Power Supply).

wan-outage.title: Wide Area Network (WAN) Outage (BSI-Style)
wan-outage.description: The causes of a Wide Area Network (WAN) failure can be diverse, affecting individual users, a provider, or an entire region.

wan-outage.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz: NET.3.2 Wide Area Network
