terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.title: Terminal Server as a Pivot Point for Lateral Movement (based on BSI T 5.150)
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.description: Terminal servers often host client-like applications (e.g., web browsers, office suites) for end users, giving them a lower level of intrinsic trust, similar to a standard client machine.
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.impact: An attacker gaining control over a terminal server can launch further attacks on other servers within the same network segment. This can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data and critical backend services, potentially causing data breaches, service disruption, and compromise of the entire server environment.
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.asvs: ASVS V14.2.1: Verify that the system is deployed in an environment that has security controls to protect it from other applications on the same server and other servers in the same environment.
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.action: Isolate Terminal Servers in a Dedicated, Restricted Network Segment
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.mitigation: Place terminal servers in their own dedicated network segment (DMZ or a specific
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.check: Review the network architecture diagram and firewall rule sets. Is the technical asset acting as a terminal server located in the same network trust boundary as other backend servers (e.g., databases, application services)? Are outbound connections from the terminal server restricted to only what is absolutely necessary?
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.detectionLogic: This rule identifies technical assets tagged with `stereotype:terminal-server`.
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.riskAssessment: The likelihood of exploitation is considered
terminal-server-as-pivot-point-for-later.falsePositives: This might be a false positive if strong, un-modeled compensating controls are in place, such as host-based firewalls on the terminal server or micro-segmentation at the hypervisor level that effectively isolates the assets despite them being in the same logical network zone.

weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.title: Weak Isolation in Shared Environment (Terminal-Server-Style Risk)
weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.description: When multiple applications or dedicated instances for different clients/tenants run on the same underlying operating system without strong isolation, there is a risk of security boundary traversal. This is common in classic terminal server or other multi-tenant environments where resources like the kernel, libraries, and file systems are shared.
weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.impact: A successful exploit can lead to unauthorized information disclosure (e.g., reading data from another session
weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.action: Enforce Strong Isolation and Hardening for Shared Environments
weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.mitigation: Prefer using environments with strong kernel-level isolation, such as modern container platforms (e.g., Docker, Podman) or full virtualization (separate VMs), over simple shared-OS multi-tenancy. Apply the principle of least privilege to all user sessions and application service accounts, strictly limiting filesystem and resource access.
weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.check: Are multiple applications from different tenants or trust levels running on a single shared OS? What isolation mechanisms are in place (e.g., containers, sandboxing, virtualization)? Are session permissions minimized? Is the host environment and all hosted software kept up-to-date with security patches?
weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for any
weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.riskAssessment: The impact is determined by the most sensitive data or critical function of any asset within the shared runtime. A breach of isolation affects the most valuable target.
weak-isolation-in-shared-environment.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive if the shared runtime technology, though abstractly modeled, implements strong, effective isolation that is not visible in the model (e.g., advanced SELinux policies, AppArmor profiles, or other sandboxing technologies).

insecure-terminal-server-communication.title: Insecure Terminal Server Communication
insecure-terminal-server-communication.description: Many terminal server protocols offer authenticated and encrypted communication. However, this is not always sufficient to secure the communication. If the protocol uses outdated and vulnerable mechanisms or if important security functions are disabled due to misconfigurations, the communication between clients and the terminal server can be intercepted. Additionally, vulnerabilities in the protocol implementation within the terminal server or client software may directly expose the server to attacks.
insecure-terminal-server-communication.impact: Information transmitted between the terminal server and clients can be intercepted or altered. This includes authentication details, user input, screen content, clipboard data, and file transfers. This can lead to data breaches, session hijacking, and direct attacks on the terminal server itself, compromising confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
insecure-terminal-server-communication.asvs: OWASP ASVS V4.0.3 - 8.1.1 (Verify that all communications to external services, or third-party services, are sent over a trusted and encrypted channel.)
insecure-terminal-server-communication.action: Ensure Secure Communication for Terminal Services
insecure-terminal-server-communication.mitigation: Use strong, encrypted protocols (such as RDP with NLA, SSH, or HTTPS-based solutions) for all terminal service communication. Ensure protocols are configured to use modern, strong ciphers and algorithms. Disable legacy protocols and features (e.g., Telnet, unencrypted RDP). Keep both terminal server and client software up to date to patch implementation vulnerabilities. Consider adding security via VPNs or IP filtering as an extra layer of protection.
insecure-terminal-server-communication.check: Is the communication protocol used for terminal access encrypted by default? Are outdated protocols disabled? Is the communication protected by a VPN? Are both server and client components regularly patched?
insecure-terminal-server-communication.detectionLogic: Checks for communication links between client-type assets and terminal-server-like assets (e.g., Application Server, Desktop, Mainframe) that use an unencrypted protocol and are not protected by other means like a VPN.
insecure-terminal-server-communication.riskAssessment: The likelihood is high if an unencrypted protocol is used across a network boundary. The impact depends on the sensitivity (CIA rating) of the terminal server and the data it processes. A server handling
insecure-terminal-server-communication.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive if the communication is secured by an underlying mechanism not modeled, such as a separate hardware VPN tunnel or network-level IPSec that is not represented by the

use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.title: Use of Group Accounts on Terminal Server (based on BSI)
use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.description: If multiple individuals need to use an application on a terminal server at different times, shared or group accounts are often set up.
use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.impact: The inability to trace user actions (lack of non-repudiation) can hinder incident response, violate legal and compliance requirements (like GDPR), and obscure malicious or erroneous activities.
use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein ORP.4 (Identity and Access Management), specifically Requirement ORP.4.A13 (Use of group accounts), which recommends avoiding group accounts where personal authentication is necessary.
use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.mitigation: Ensure that every user accessing the terminal server authenticates with a unique, individual account.
use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.check: Are group accounts used for interactive access to the terminal server? Can all actions performed on the server be unambiguously traced back to a specific individual?
use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.detectionLogic: This risk is detected by identifying technical assets tagged as a `@Service:TerminalServer`.
use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered high because the model explicitly shows a lack of individual user identity propagation.
use-of-group-accounts-on-terminal-server.falsePositives: A false positive can occur if the model is inaccurate, for example, if an `enduser-identity-propagation` mechanism is in place but not correctly documented in the communication link

overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.title: Overly Restrictive Terminal Server Configuration Leading to Insecure Workarounds
overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.description: A terminal server, or similar multi-user application host, can function as both a server and, for the applications running on it, a client.
overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.impact: When essential tasks are blocked by overly restrictive policies, users may resort to insecure and unmonitored workarounds.
overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz principles for secure system operation. While not a direct ASVS web application requirement, it relates to the broader security principle of proper access control (ASVS V4.0.3 Chapter 4) and secure configuration.
overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.action: Balance Terminal Server Security Restrictions with User Experience and Functionality
overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.mitigation: Review the configuration of terminal servers and similar application hosts to ensure that security restrictions do not impede essential business functions.
overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.check: Are the access control policies on terminal-server-like assets reviewed for usability? Are there sanctioned and easy-to-use methods for data import/export that meet user needs?
overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for technical assets that function as multi-user application hosts (e.g., `application-server`, `desktop`) and are used directly by human clients.
overly-restrictive-terminal-server-confi.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered higher when sensitive data is being handled, as the pressure on users to complete their tasks may lead them to take greater risks.

insufficient-testing-of-terminal-server-.title: Insufficient Testing of Application Compatibility on Terminal Server / VDI (BSI SYS.3.2.2)
insufficient-testing-of-terminal-server-.description: Not all applications can be deployed on any terminal server or virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI).
insufficient-testing-of-terminal-server-.impact: Failure to ensure compatibility for hardware-dependent applications on a shared or virtualized platform can lead to a significant or total loss of availability for that application.
insufficient-testing-of-terminal-server-.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein SYS.3.2.2 Terminalserver. This risk deals with ensuring the operational fitness of applications in a terminal server environment.
insufficient-testing-of-terminal-server-.mitigation: Before deploying an application with special hardware requirements (like GPU acceleration or specific peripherals) onto a terminal server, VDI, or other shared runtime,
insufficient-testing-of-terminal-server-.check: Has the application been fully tested on the target terminal server or shared runtime environment?

malware-on-client-systems.title: Malware Infection on Client Systems (BSI DER.1)
malware-on-client-systems.description: Malware is designed to execute unwanted and malicious functions on IT systems, often operating covertly without the user
malware-on-client-systems.impact: A successful malware infection on a client can lead to the compromise of confidentiality (e.g., theft of credentials and sensitive data), integrity (e.g., data manipulation, ransomware encryption), and availability (e.g., system crashes, denial-of-service). The infection can also serve as a beachhead for further attacks into the corporate network, escalating the potential damage significantly.
malware-on-client-systems.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz: DER.1 Bedrohungen durch Schadprogramme, SYS.2.1 Allgemeiner Client
malware-on-client-systems.action: Implement Multi-Layered Endpoint Protection and User Awareness
malware-on-client-systems.mitigation: Employ a defense-in-depth strategy for clients. This includes centrally managed and up-to-date endpoint protection software (antivirus/EDR), application whitelisting, host-based firewalls, and regular security patching. Restrict user permissions to the minimum necessary. Implement web and email filtering to block malicious content at the gateway. Control the use of removable media. Complement technical measures with a continuous security awareness program for all users.
malware-on-client-systems.check: Are all client systems equipped with managed and updated endpoint security software? Are operating systems and applications regularly patched? Is the principle of least privilege enforced for user accounts? Are there technical controls for web, email, and removable media? Is there an active security awareness program?
malware-on-client-systems.detectionLogic: This risk is automatically detected for all technical assets identified as client systems (e.g., Browser, Desktop, Mobile App). The risk
malware-on-client-systems.riskAssessment: The likelihood of infection is considered high for internet-facing clients operated by humans. The impact is determined by the CIA requirements of the client itself, the data it processes, and the criticality of the backend systems it connects to. A client used to administer mission-critical systems poses a very-high impact risk.
malware-on-client-systems.falsePositives: The risk may be overestimated if the model does not capture specific hardening measures or compensating controls like a fully restrictive VDI environment or kiosk mode. Manual verification of the client

exclusive-local-data-storage.title: Exclusive Local Data Storage
exclusive-local-data-storage.description: Despite contrary recommendations, important data is often stored exclusively locally, for example, in local file directories or email archives instead of on a central file server.
exclusive-local-data-storage.impact: Storing important data exclusively on local systems poses a significant risk to its availability and integrity.
exclusive-local-data-storage.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz CON.3 (Data Backup Concept) and APP.4.5 (Notebooks).
exclusive-local-data-storage.action: Implement and Enforce Centralized Data Storage and Backup
exclusive-local-data-storage.mitigation: Establish and enforce a clear policy for storing all important institutional data on central, managed systems (e.g., file servers, databases, enterprise cloud storage).
exclusive-local-data-storage.check: Is there a policy mandating central storage for important data? Are suitable central storage systems available, known to users, and actively used?
exclusive-local-data-storage.detectionLogic: This rule identifies client-type technical assets (e.g., desktops, mobile apps) that store important data locally but lack a modeled communication link to a central datastore (like a database or file server).
exclusive-local-data-storage.riskAssessment: The likelihood of a hardware failure or other loss event is considered
exclusive-local-data-storage.falsePositives: A risk might be flagged if a backup or synchronization mechanism (e.g., a cloud sync client like OneDrive or Dropbox) is active on the client system but not represented as a communication link in the model.

physical-damage-to-client-devices.title: Physical Damage to Client Devices (BSI T 0.15, T 0.16)
physical-damage-to-client-devices.description: Unlike central IT systems like servers, users interact directly with client devices. This proximity means users might, intentionally or unintentionally, damage the device.
physical-damage-to-client-devices.impact: If a client device is damaged, lost, or stolen, it cannot be used as intended until it is repaired or replaced, which directly impacts availability.
physical-damage-to-client-devices.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Threats T 0.15 (Failure or disruption of devices or systems) and T 0.16 (Destruction of devices or data media), often discussed in modules like OPS.1.2.2 (Laptops).
physical-damage-to-client-devices.action: Implement Physical and Environmental Protection for Client Devices
physical-damage-to-client-devices.mitigation: Use protective cases and screen protectors for mobile devices. Implement robust cable management to reduce tripping hazards.
physical-damage-to-client-devices.check: Are there physical protection measures in place for client devices (e.g., laptop cases, secure workstations)? Is full-disk encryption enforced?
physical-damage-to-client-devices.detectionLogic: This risk is triggered for all in-scope technical assets identified as client-type technologies using the
physical-damage-to-client-devices.riskAssessment: The impact is directly proportional to the Availability requirement of the asset and the work performed by its user.
physical-damage-to-client-devices.falsePositives: This risk might be considered a false positive or have a lower likelihood if the client device is located in a highly controlled environment where user-induced physical damage is extremely improbable (e.g., a kiosk in a locked, protected enclosure).

unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.title: Unauthorized Client Access (BSI SYS.3.1)
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.description: Identification and authentication are intended to prevent unauthorized use of a client. However, IT systems requiring user ID and password authentication can still be used without authorization if an attacker manages to spy on or guess the credentials. If a screen lock is not activated, the client can also be used without authorization during brief absences.
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.impact: Unauthorized access to a client system can lead to theft of sensitive data (compromising confidentiality), manipulation of data or system functions (compromising integrity), and misuse of the system for further attacks within the network. This can result in financial loss, reputational damage, and breaches of legal or contractual obligations.
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein SYS.3.1 (Client under Windows), specifically Requirements SYS.3.1.A5 (Authentication at the client) and SYS.3.1.A6 (Screen lock).
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.action: Enforce Strong Client Authentication and Automatic Screen Locking
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.mitigation: Enforce strong authentication mechanisms on all client systems, preferably Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). Implement and enforce a strict password policy for complexity, rotation, and history where passwords are used. Configure all clients to automatically lock the screen after a short period of inactivity. Educate users about the risks of weak credentials, shoulder surfing, and social engineering attacks.
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.check: Is MFA required for client login? Is there a password policy in place and is it enforced? Are all client devices configured to auto-lock after a short period of inactivity? Are users trained on credential security?
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.detectionLogic: This risk applies to all in-scope technical assets identified as human-operated clients (e.g., technology types
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.riskAssessment: The likelihood is HIGH for clients with no authentication or just a simple password. It is MEDIUM for clients with strong passwords but no MFA. It is LOW for clients enforcing MFA or biometric authentication. The impact is determined by the CIA rating of the client asset itself and the sensitivity of the data it processes or stores.
unauthorized-client-access-sys3.1.falsePositives: This rule might generate a false positive if the client authentication method is managed by an external Identity Provider and this is not reflected in the model via tags. The risk should be manually verified against the actual client configuration.

unnecessary-software-on-client.title: Unnecessary Software on Client (BSI-Style Hardening Principle)
unnecessary-software-on-client.description: When installing an operating system, there is usually the option to install optional software.
unnecessary-software-on-client.impact: Exploiting a vulnerability in unnecessary and unpatched software can lead to a full compromise of the client system.
unnecessary-software-on-client.asvs: Derived from general system hardening best practices, similar to CIS Benchmarks. It aligns with the principle of minimizing the attack surface.
unnecessary-software-on-client.action: Implement Strict Software Installation Policies and Hardening
unnecessary-software-on-client.mitigation: Enforce a strict policy that only essential, approved software is installed on client systems.
unnecessary-software-on-client.check: Is there an application whitelisting solution in place on clients? Is there a formal process for approving and installing software?
unnecessary-software-on-client.detectionLogic: This risk applies to all in-scope technical assets identified as clients (e.g., desktops, mobile apps, developer clients).
unnecessary-software-on-client.riskAssessment: The likelihood of exploitation is higher for clients with internet access.
unnecessary-software-on-client.falsePositives: This risk can be a false positive if the organization has strong, enforced hardening policies that are not reflected in the model via tags.

unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.title: Unauthorized Eavesdropping via Client Device Peripherals
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.description: Many client systems, including desktops, mobile devices, and IoT devices like Intelligent Personal Assistants (IPAs), are equipped with microphones and cameras.
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.impact: Unauthorized activation of microphones or cameras leads to a direct breach of confidentiality.
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz; similar concepts in OWASP MASVS (Mobile App Security) V8.1:
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.action: Harden Client Endpoints and Enforce Strict Access Control on Peripherals
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.mitigation: Implement a robust endpoint security policy for all client devices. This should include OS hardening, using endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions, and strictly managing application permissions to access hardware like microphones and cameras.
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.check: Is there an endpoint security solution in place for all client devices? Are application permissions to use microphones and cameras regularly audited?
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for any in-scope technical asset classified as a client-type technology (e.g., ClientSystem, MobileApp, IoTDevice) that is tagged as having a microphone or camera.
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.riskAssessment: The impact of this risk is directly proportional to the confidentiality of the information in the physical environment where the device is located. A device in a public area has a low impact, while one in a boardroom has a very high impact.
unauthorized-eavesdropping-via-client-de.falsePositives: The risk might be a false positive if the device is located in a non-sensitive environment where no confidential information is ever discussed, or if the peripherals are verifiably physically disconnected.

misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.title: Misconfiguration or Improper Use of Client System (BSI-Style)
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.description: Modern client operating systems are highly complex. Misconfigurations of components can significantly impair security, leading to system malfunctions or compromises.
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.impact: If this risk is exploited, an attacker could gain unauthorized access to the client system and any connected resources. This can lead to the compromise of
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein SYS.3.1 (Clients under Windows), SYS.3.2.1 (Clients under Linux), and SYS.3.3 (Clients under macOS). This risk consolidates the general threat of misconfiguration applicable to all client systems.
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.action: Harden and Secure Client System Configurations and Promote Secure User Practices
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.mitigation: Implement and enforce hardened standard configurations (baselines) for all client systems using configuration management tools like GPO or MDM.
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.check: Are there documented, hardened security baselines for all client operating systems in use? Is a centralized configuration management system (like GPO or MDM) in place to enforce these baselines?
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for all in-scope technical assets identified as client systems (e.g., desktops, mobile apps, browsers, etc.).
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered high for internet-facing clients and medium for internal-only clients, assuming no specific hardening measures are modeled.
misconfiguration-or-improper-use-of-clie.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive if the client systems are already managed and hardened by robust, out-of-model processes (e.g., a mature corporate GPO/MDM environment).

high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.title: High Risk Profile for Windows Systems (BSI-based)
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.description: Due to the high prevalence of Windows operating systems and the backward compatibility often present between system generations,
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.impact: If this risk materializes, malware or unauthorized access can compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the system and the data it processes.
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz: SYS.1.2 Windows Server, SYS.1.3 Windows Clients
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.action: Implement Robust Hardening, Patch Management, and Endpoint Protection for Windows Systems
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.mitigation: Apply a defense-in-depth strategy for all Windows systems. This includes:
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.check: Are all Windows systems covered by a patch management process with defined SLAs? Is there a documented hardening standard for Windows systems that is actively enforced and audited?
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.detectionLogic: This risk is triggered for all in-scope technical assets identified as a Windows system via the `@OS:Windows` tag.
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered high due to the large attack surface and the constant barrage of attacks targeting Windows vulnerabilities.
high-risk-profile-for-windows-systems.falsePositives: This generalized risk is rarely a complete false positive, as the external threat landscape for Windows is a given.

software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.title: Software Incompatibility on OS Upgrade (based on BSI)
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.description: Software, especially older applications that were successfully operated on previous versions of an operating system, may not be compatible with current OS versions.
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.impact: If an application is incompatible with an OS upgrade, it can lead to a partial or complete loss of its functionality.
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.asvs: This is a platform-level configuration and lifecycle management issue, not directly covered by OWASP ASVS which focuses on web application security. The closest concept is ensuring a secure and stable operating environment.
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.action: Establish and Execute an Application Compatibility Testing Process
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.mitigation: Before deploying major OS updates to production environments, critical applications must be tested for compatibility in a representative staging environment.
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.check: Is there a formal process for testing application compatibility before OS upgrades? Is there an up-to-date inventory of critical applications and their supported operating systems?
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for technical assets that are likely to be sensitive to underlying OS changes.
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.riskAssessment: The likelihood of this risk materializing is higher for applications explicitly marked as legacy or for older, complex COTS software.
software-incompatibility-on-os-upgrade.falsePositives: This risk may be a false positive if the organization has a robust, consistently executed pre-deployment testing process or if the specific application is already confirmed to be compatible by the vendor. The risk serves as a prompt to verify that these operational controls are in place.

windows-telemetry-data-leakage.title: Undesired Windows Telemetry Data Transmission
windows-telemetry-data-leakage.description: By default, Windows sends diagnostic data to the manufacturer, Microsoft. Additionally, Microsoft can specifically query information from a client via the integrated telemetry service.
windows-telemetry-data-leakage.impact: If sensitive data is exfiltrated via the telemetry service, it constitutes a confidentiality breach. This could lead to the exposure of business secrets, personal data, or other protected information, potentially resulting in legal, financial, or reputational damage.
windows-telemetry-data-leakage.asvs: This is a platform/OS-level configuration risk, not directly covered by OWASP ASVS. It relates to secure system configuration and hardening, similar in spirit to BSI IT-Grundschutz
windows-telemetry-data-leakage.mitigation: As part of the client hardening process, the level of diagnostic data sent to Microsoft should be explicitly configured and restricted.
windows-telemetry-data-leakage.check: Are Windows clients hardened to restrict telemetry data collection? Is the diagnostic data level explicitly set to a minimal required level (e.g.,
windows-telemetry-data-leakage.detectionLogic: This rule triggers for in-scope technical assets identified as Windows clients (e.g., technology
windows-telemetry-data-leakage.riskAssessment: The likelihood of data transmission is
windows-telemetry-data-leakage.falsePositives: This risk can be a false positive if telemetry is controlled by other means not represented in the model (e.g., a network-level proxy blocking all telemetry endpoints), or if the specific Windows edition used (e.g., Enterprise LTSC) has different, more secure defaults.

impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.title: Impaired Forensics Due to Virtual Secure Mode (VSM)
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.description: The use of Virtual Secure Mode (VSM) restricts or complicates forensic investigations, for example, during security incident response. Processes protected by the Secure Kernel or Isolated User Mode (IUM) become inaccessible. For instance, memory dumps of these processes cannot be analyzed due to cryptographic measures, impeding the ability to investigate security incidents on the asset.
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.impact: This severely hinders the ability to conduct effective security incident response and forensic analysis. It can be impossible to determine the root cause of an incident, the extent of a compromise, or the actions taken by an attacker. This can lead to prolonged system downtime, incomplete remediation, and an inability to meet legal or compliance requirements for incident reporting and analysis.
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz CON.8 (Incident Management and Response). The inability to perform forensics directly impacts the analysis and handling phase of an incident.
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.action: Assess and Document Forensic Implications of VSM
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.mitigation: Before enabling VSM or similar hardware-based isolation technologies, perform a risk assessment. The benefits of process isolation must be weighed against the operational cost of impaired forensic capabilities. Ensure that alternative monitoring, logging, and detection mechanisms are in place to compensate for the loss of direct memory access (e.g., enhance application-level logging, network traffic analysis, or EDR solutions aware of VSM). Document the accepted risk and the compensatory controls.
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.check: Is VSM or a similar technology in use on the asset? If so, is there a documented risk assessment acknowledging the impact on forensics? Are there enhanced, alternative logging and monitoring controls in place for the protected components?
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.detectionLogic: Detects technical assets that are explicitly tagged as having Virtual Secure Mode (VSM) enabled. The presence of this technology inherently complicates or blocks standard forensic procedures like memory analysis.
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.riskAssessment: The likelihood of forensic impairment is considered
impaired-forensics-due-to-vsm.falsePositives: This risk can be considered a false positive if the organization has specific, VSM-aware forensic tools and documented procedures that provide equivalent visibility into protected processes, effectively mitigating the risk.

unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.title: Unauthorized Software Installation on Unix-like Systems
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.description: On Unix-like IT systems, users might download and compile source code themselves or install pre-compiled packages from unverified third-party sources, bypassing official distribution repositories.
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.impact: The installation of untrusted software can introduce malware, leading to a complete compromise of the system
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.asvs: V14.2.5: Verify that third-party components are from a trusted source, have been securely transported, and have not been modified.
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.action: Enforce Strict Software Installation and Sourcing Policies
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.mitigation: Restrict software installation privileges to authorized administrators only. Configure package managers to use only trusted, official repositories and verify package signatures.
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.check: Are user permissions configured to prevent unauthorized software installation? Are package manager repositories restricted to official, signed sources?
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.detectionLogic: This risk applies to technical assets identified as Unix-like systems, which are often targets for this type of compromise.
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.riskAssessment: The likelihood is high if non-administrative users have shell access and write permissions in their home directories on a multi-user system.
unauthorized-software-on-unix-systems.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive if the model does not capture strong compensating controls.

misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.title: Misuse of Scripting Languages on Unix-like Systems
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.description: On Unix-like operating systems, scripting languages (bash, sh, Python, Perl, Ruby, etc.) are powerful and deeply integrated.
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.impact: If an attacker can execute unauthorized scripts, they may compromise confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the entire client and surrounding infrastructure.
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.asvs: OWASP ASVS V14.2.1 (Command Injection) / BSI SYS.2.3 §2.2
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.action: Lock Down Script Interpreters and Execution Paths
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.mitigation: Apply least privilege end-to-end. Remove or disable interpreters that are not strictly needed.
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.check: Are unnecessary interpreters removed? Are SELinux/AppArmor profiles enforcing and allow-listing script execution?
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.detectionLogic: Raised for in-scope technical assets tagged
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.riskAssessment: Likelihood is higher for internet-facing systems and unmanaged endpoints. Impact derives from the asset criticality and the sensitivity of processed/stored data.
misuse-of-scripting-languages-on-unix-li.falsePositives: May be a false positive if strong controls are demonstrably enforced (e.g., SELinux/AppArmor enforcing with minimal policy,

conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.title: Conflicting Configurations on Unix-like Clients (BSI-based)
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.description: On Unix-like client systems, numerous applications are installed, each with its own configuration files.
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.impact: Conflicting configurations can cause unintended behavior, creating security vulnerabilities and operational issues.
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.asvs: Inspired by BSI IT-Grundschutz. Related to OWASP ASVS v4.0.3: 14.1 Configuration.
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.action: Implement centralized configuration management and regular audits
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.mitigation: Utilize configuration management and infrastructure-as-code tools (e.g., Ansible, Puppet, Chef, Terraform) to enforce a consistent, conflict-free, and version-controlled configuration state.
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.check: Is a centralized configuration management system in use? Is there a documented, secure baseline configuration for the client?
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for technical assets that represent complex systems likely to have multifaceted configurations (e.g., application servers, databases, container platforms).
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.riskAssessment: The likelihood is higher for systems with a large number of applications or complex integration patterns (many communication links).
conflicting-configurations-on-complex-sy.falsePositives: This risk may be a false positive if the system, despite its complexity, is managed by a robust, fully automated configuration management system designed to prevent or immediately detect such conflicts. Manual verification of operational practices is required.

inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.title: Inadequate NAC Planning and Implementation (BSI NET.3.1)
inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.description: If planning for a Network Access Control (NAC) solution is inadequate, for example due to an incomplete IT asset inventory or insufficient requirements analysis, significant security gaps can arise.
inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.impact: A poorly implemented NAC solution can lead to Elevation of Privilege, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive network segments and data. It can also cause denial of service for legitimate users and systems.
inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.action: Implement and validate a comprehensive Network Access Control (NAC) solution
inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.mitigation: Ensure a complete and up-to-date IT asset inventory is maintained. Perform a thorough requirements analysis for the NAC solution, considering all relevant systems, protocols, and user roles.
inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.check: Is there a complete inventory of all assets that require network access? Are strong, standardized authentication and authorization methods enforced for all connections that cross trust boundaries?
inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.detectionLogic: This risk is identified by analyzing communication links that cross network trust boundaries. The risk is triggered when such a connection uses weak or no authentication or authorization, a strong indicator of an inadequate or misconfigured NAC.
inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.riskAssessment: The likelihood of exploitation is high if authentication is missing entirely on a boundary-crossing link. The impact is determined by the Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability (CIA) rating of the target asset and the data it processes or stores.
inadequate-nac-planning-net-3-1.falsePositives: A risk might be flagged for a link that is protected by an intermediate security component (such as a WAF or IPS) not explicitly modeled in Threagile.

inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.title: Inadequate Endpoint Orchestration for NAC (BSI NET.3.2)
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.description: A lack of—or inadequately implemented—endpoint orchestration tools, security policies, and resources can lead to poor integration of devices into a Network Access Control (NAC) solution.
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.impact: If unmanaged or poorly configured endpoints connect to the network, they can bypass security controls. This may lead to unauthorized access to sensitive network segments, the use of weak authentication credentials, and potential data breaches. It also increases the risk of compromised devices gaining a foothold in the internal network, potentially leading to elevation of privilege, information disclosure, and denial of service.
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.asvs: Derived from the BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein NET.3.2 (Network Access Control)
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.action: Implement centralized endpoint management and NAC integration policies
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.mitigation: Use a centralized orchestration tool (such as UEM or MDM) to manage all endpoints. Define and enforce security policies for different endpoint groups (e.g., corporate, BYOD, IoT).
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.check: Is a centralized endpoint orchestration tool (UEM/MDM) in use? Are security policies defined for different endpoint types? Is there a standardized onboarding process for new devices that includes NAC registration? Does the NAC enforce network segmentation based on endpoint identity and compliance status? Is strong authentication required for access to critical resources?
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.detectionLogic: This risk is triggered for client-type technical assets (e.g., Desktop, MobileApp, IoTDevice) that are not explicitly marked as managed (e.g., via an `@EndpointManaged` tag).
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered high if numerous unmanaged client devices can connect to the network. The impact is determined by the sensitivity (CIA ratings) of the assets they can reach. Access to mission-critical systems or strictly confidential data from an unmanaged device constitutes a very high impact.
inadequate-endpoint-orchestration-for-na.falsePositives: The model might not include the endpoint management or orchestration system as a technical asset. An organization may have a robust endpoint management solution in place that is not reflected in the diagram, making this risk a false positive. Verification of operational processes and tools is required.

insecure-wlan-or-nac-authentication.title: Insecure WLAN or Network Access Control (NAC) Authentication
insecure-wlan-or-nac-authentication.description: If secure authentication methods for network access (such as EAP-TLS in an 802.1X environment) are not supported or enforced,
insecure-wlan-or-nac-authentication.impact: An attacker could impersonate a legitimate client device and gain an initial foothold on an internal network segment.
insecure-wlan-or-nac-authentication.asvs: Derived from BSI IT-Grundschutz Baustein NET.3.2 (WLAN Usage) and NET.1.1 (Network Architecture).
insecure-wlan-or-nac-authentication.mitigation: For 802.1X-based network access (wired or wireless), enforce strong EAP types such as EAP-TLS, which require both client and server certificates.
insecure-wlan-or-nac-authentication.check: Is 802.1X deployed for network access? If so, which EAP types are permitted by the RADIUS server configuration?
insecure-wlan-or-nac-authentication.detectionLogic: This risk triggers for communication links originating from client-type assets (e.g., mobile apps, desktops, IoT devices) that cross a network trust boundary
insecure-wlan-or-nac-authentication.riskAssessment: The likelihood of exploitation is high when a weak authentication protocol is used for network access, as tools for such attacks are widely available.

misconfigured-nac-ruleset.title: Misconfigured NAC Ruleset
misconfigured-nac-ruleset.description: Due to human error, inadequate processes, or insufficient staffing that leads to time constraints,
misconfigured-nac-ruleset.impact: A misconfigured NAC solution can lead to two primary outcomes. First, it can cause a denial of service, where legitimate endpoints
misconfigured-nac-ruleset.action: Implement the four-eyes principle and auditing for NAC configuration changes
misconfigured-nac-ruleset.mitigation: All changes to the NAC ruleset (on RADIUS servers, access switches, etc.) must follow a documented change management process,
misconfigured-nac-ruleset.check: Is there a documented process for managing changes to NAC configurations? Are all changes subject to peer review? Are NAC configurations and access logs regularly audited?
misconfigured-nac-ruleset.detectionLogic: Identifies technical assets that are central components of a Network Access Control system, such as RADIUS servers or enforcing access switches.
misconfigured-nac-ruleset.falsePositives: This risk is reported for any asset tagged as a core NAC component. It may be considered a false positive if the organization has exceptionally robust,

insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.title: Insufficient Network Access Control (BSI NET.3.2)
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.description: If Network Access Control (NAC) is disabled—temporarily or permanently—or not implemented at network boundaries (e.g., switch ports), network access is insufficiently protected.
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.impact: Unauthorized network access can compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information assets.
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz NET.3.2 Network Access Control, especially requirement NET.3.2.A2 (use of a NAC system). Also related to NET.1.1.A5 (controlling access to a LAN).
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.action: Implement and enforce strong network access control
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.mitigation: Ensure that all network access points—especially those crossing trust boundaries—are protected by a robust NAC solution that authenticates and authorizes every device or user attempting to connect.
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.check: Do any communication links in the model cross a network trust boundary without authentication? Are VPNs or IP filtering used as compensating controls?
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.detectionLogic: This risk is detected by identifying communication links that cross a network trust boundary without any authentication (`authentication: none`).
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.riskAssessment: Likelihood is high whenever an unprotected entry point into a sensitive network exists.
insufficient-network-access-control-bsi-.falsePositives: A false positive may occur if a compensating control exists but is not modeled (e.g., a physical stateful firewall between the assets).

nac-component-failure.title: Failure of Network Access Control (NAC) Components
nac-component-failure.description: An inadequately designed or implemented NAC architecture, malfunctioning NAC components, network disruptions, or denial-of-service (DoS) attacks can cause the failure or unavailability of central NAC components. This directly affects the ability of endpoints to communicate and can result in two critical failure modes, depending on how network enforcement points (e.g., switches, wireless access points) are configured.
nac-component-failure.impact: If an enforcement point is configured to
nac-component-failure.asvs: V14.2.1: Verify that all networked components—including servers, workstations, and network devices—are securely configured.
nac-component-failure.action: Implement a resilient NAC architecture and define failure modes
nac-component-failure.mitigation: Ensure high availability for all central NAC components (e.g., RADIUS servers) through redundancy (e.g., clustered servers). Explicitly define and implement the desired failure mode (fail-open vs. fail-closed) on all NAC enforcement points based on a thorough risk assessment for each network segment. Harden NAC components against DoS attacks. Continuously monitor the health and availability of all NAC components and the underlying network infrastructure.
nac-component-failure.check: Are central NAC components designed and deployed in a highly available, redundant configuration? Is the failure mode (fail-open/fail-closed) explicitly configured on all network enforcement devices? Is the health of all NAC components actively monitored with alerting?
nac-component-failure.detectionLogic: This rule identifies technical assets tagged `@NAC-Component:true` that are non-redundant. It then checks for direct communication links to network devices tagged with `@NAC-Enforcement-Point:fail-open` or `@NAC-Enforcement-Point:fail-closed`. Based on the enforcement point
nac-component-failure.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered high if a critical NAC component is not configured redundantly. The impact is determined by the failure mode. For
nac-component-failure.falsePositives: This risk may be a false positive if redundancy is achieved through mechanisms not represented in the model (e.g., cloud-native load balancing, DNS failover) or if the tagged component is not actually critical for network access.

inadequate-protection-of-log-data.title: Inadequate Protection of Personally Identifiable Log Data
inadequate-protection-of-log-data.description: An inadequate administrative concept, poor implementation, excessively long data retention periods, or insufficient coordination with the works council and the data protection officer can lead to inadequate protection of personally identifiable log data. These conditions increase the risk of data misuse.
inadequate-protection-of-log-data.impact: If personally identifiable log data is not adequately protected or is stored for too long without a clear policy, it could be misused to create detailed user profiles. This enables tracking of employee activities and behavior over time, leading to significant privacy violations. Such incidents can result in legal and financial penalties (e.g., under the GDPR), reputational damage, and loss of trust from employees and customers.
inadequate-protection-of-log-data.asvs: V8.3.4: All sensitive data at rest is encrypted, using a recommended and proven algorithm and a strong encryption key.
inadequate-protection-of-log-data.action: Implement Data Minimization and Retention Policies for Log Data
inadequate-protection-of-log-data.mitigation: Define and enforce strict data-retention policies for all log data, especially where personal information is involved. Ensure that logs are deleted or anonymized automatically after the defined retention period. Access to raw log data must be tightly controlled and restricted to authorized personnel with a legitimate need. Consult the data protection officer and, where applicable, the works council to ensure compliance with legal requirements such as the GDPR. Use the `@RetentionPolicy:Defined` tag on technical assets to indicate that such a policy exists and is enforced for the data stored there.
inadequate-protection-of-log-data.check: Are data-retention policies for logs clearly defined and documented? Is there an automated process for deleting or anonymizing old logs? Is access to log management systems properly secured and audited? Has the data protection officer (and, where applicable, the works council) approved the logging and retention strategy?
inadequate-protection-of-log-data.detectionLogic: This rule triggers on technical assets likely to store or process log data (e.g., databases, monitoring systems, data lakes) that handle data assets identified as sensitive, personally identifiable logs. A risk is generated if such a technical asset is not explicitly tagged with `@RetentionPolicy:Defined`, indicating a potential lack of required data-lifecycle management.
inadequate-protection-of-log-data.falsePositives: A risk may be flagged even if a retention policy exists but is managed outside the system documented in the threat model. In such cases, update the model by applying the `@RetentionPolicy:Defined` tag to the relevant technical asset to suppress this finding.

file-server-availability-failure.title: Availability Failure of a Fileserver (BSI-based)
file-server-availability-failure.description: If a fileserver fails, the entire information system—including key business processes and institutional tasks—can be affected. Not only users but also applications may depend on data from the fileserver to operate correctly. The BSI warns that such failures can cause serious operational disruptions.
file-server-availability-failure.impact: If the availability of data and services on the fileserver is not ensured, deadlines may be missed and essential business processes interrupted. Without an emergency management plan, restart times can increase further. In many cases, this results in financial losses, and the outage may also affect other institutions.
file-server-availability-failure.asvs: V6.1: Verify all application components have sufficient availability to handle application load, and can gracefully handle failures in integrated systems.
file-server-availability-failure.action: Implement redundancy, backup and recovery, and disaster recovery plans
file-server-availability-failure.mitigation: Fileservers, especially those storing critical data, should be designed for high availability. This can be achieved through redundant hardware, clustering, or load balancing. A robust backup and recovery strategy must be in place and regularly tested. For mission-critical systems, a comprehensive disaster recovery plan should be established to ensure business continuity. The `redundant` flag on the technical asset should be set to `true` to reflect such a setup.
file-server-availability-failure.check: Is the fileserver asset marked as
file-server-availability-failure.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for any technical asset of type
file-server-availability-failure.falsePositives: This risk may be a false positive if redundancy is handled by an underlying platform (e.g., cloud storage backend, SAN with failover) that is not explicitly modeled, but which effectively makes the fileserver component highly available. In such cases, the `redundant: true` flag should be set on the asset.

insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.title: Insufficient File Server Resources (BSI CON.1.A15)
insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.description: If the network connection or storage capacity of the file server is insufficient, access times can increase or storage bottlenecks can occur.
insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.impact: Inadequate resources for a file server can directly impact availability and can lead to integrity issues if applications fail.
insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz CON.1.A15 (Sufficient dimensioning of the file server)
insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.action: Implement Capacity and Performance Management for File Servers
insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.check: Are performance and capacity metrics for the file server actively monitored? Is there a documented process for capacity planning?
insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for all technical assets of the
insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.riskAssessment: The likelihood is determined by factors indicating high load, such as the number of incoming connections and the volume of data stored.
insufficient-fileserver-resources-con1-a.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive if the file server, even under high load, is adequately sized, properly monitored, and supported by a well-managed capacity plan.

malware-on-fileserver.title: Unprotected File Server Spreading Malware
malware-on-fileserver.description: If a file server is insufficiently integrated into the organization
malware-on-fileserver.impact: Widespread malware infection can compromise the Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability (CIA) of data across numerous systems.
malware-on-fileserver.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz OPS.1.1.4 Protection against malware
malware-on-fileserver.action: Integrate the File Server into the Malware Protection Strategy
malware-on-fileserver.mitigation: Ensure that the file server is covered by the central malware protection strategy. This includes installing and regularly updating anti-malware software on the file server itself,
malware-on-fileserver.check: Is the file server asset in the threat model tagged with `@Protected:Anti-Malware`? Does this reflect reality, i.e., is the server equipped with an effective, up-to-date anti-malware solution that scans file shares?
malware-on-fileserver.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for any in-scope technical asset of type
malware-on-fileserver.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered higher if the file server is exposed to the internet. The impact is determined by the highest CIA rating of the file server itself or the data it stores.
malware-on-fileserver.falsePositives: A file server might have malware protection in place, but this is not documented in the model using the `@Protected:Anti-Malware` tag.

improper-access-control-orp4.title: Improper Access Control (BSI ORP.4)
improper-access-control-orp4.description: If access rights and permissions are not properly designed, assigned, and enforced, unauthorized parties may gain access to data. This could allow them to read, modify, or delete sensitive information, compromising confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
improper-access-control-orp4.impact: Failing to enforce proper access control can lead to data breaches, unauthorized manipulation or deletion of data, and elevation-of-privilege attacks. Consequences can include financial loss, reputational damage, operational disruption, and non-compliance with legal or contractual obligations.
improper-access-control-orp4.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz ORP.4 Identity and Access Management, particularly ORP.4.A6 (Definition of authorisations) and ORP.4.A7 (Setting up users and authorisations).
improper-access-control-orp4.action: Implement and enforce strong access control
improper-access-control-orp4.mitigation: Ensure that all communication links, especially those accessing data stores or processing sensitive information, enforce strong authentication and authorization mechanisms (e.g., using tokens, client certificates, or identity propagation rather than
improper-access-control-orp4.check: Are there any communication links in the model with `authentication` or `authorization` set to `none`? Do these links transmit or receive data assets? What is the sensitivity of the data and the target asset?
improper-access-control-orp4.detectionLogic: This rule triggers when a communication link has its `authentication` or `authorization` property set to `none`. The risk is raised against the target asset of that link, as it is the component failing to enforce access control, especially if it handles sensitive data or is otherwise critical.
improper-access-control-orp4.riskAssessment: The likelihood of exploitation is considered very high when no access controls are present on a communication channel. The impact is calculated based on the highest Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability ratings of both the data assets transferred over the link and the target asset itself. Higher CIA ratings lead to higher impact.
improper-access-control-orp4.falsePositives: This risk might be a false positive if the data being transferred is explicitly intended for public, unauthenticated access and its integrity is not a concern (e.g., a public status page with no user data). It is more likely to be a modeling error where access controls exist but were not documented in the threat model.

disorganized-data-storage-con1.title: Unstructured Data Storage (BSI CON.1)
disorganized-data-storage-con1.description: If a storage structure is not specified, or if employees do not adhere to it,
disorganized-data-storage-con1.impact: Unstructured data storage can compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information.
disorganized-data-storage-con1.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz CON.1.A1: Definition of a Directory Structure
disorganized-data-storage-con1.action: Define and Enforce Data Storage Structures and Policies
disorganized-data-storage-con1.mitigation: Establish and document a clear, well-structured, and mandatory directory and file structure for all relevant data stores.
disorganized-data-storage-con1.check: Is there a documented and enforced policy for file and directory structures? Are access permissions regularly reviewed?
disorganized-data-storage-con1.detectionLogic: This risk is raised for technical assets of type
disorganized-data-storage-con1.riskAssessment: The likelihood is considered higher for multi-tenant assets or those with a large number of users, as this increases the potential for disorganization.

data-loss-on-fileserver.title: Data Loss on File Server due to Missing Redundancy or Backup
data-loss-on-fileserver.description: If a file server fails completely or individual components fail, important information can be lost without file synchronization or a functioning backup. The same applies if employees accidentally delete files. If sufficient redundancy (e.g., a suitable Redundant Array of Independent Disks (RAID)) is not employed, further problems can arise. The failure of a single storage device can directly disrupt operations because the files are no longer available.
data-loss-on-fileserver.impact: A failure without proper redundancy or backup leads to data loss, compromising Integrity (data is lost or incomplete) and Availability (data is not accessible). This can severely disrupt operations, cause permanent loss of valuable information, and result in significant operational and financial damage.
data-loss-on-fileserver.asvs: BSI IT-Grundschutz: APP.3.3 Fileserver (Section 2.6 – loss of data); see also CON.3 Datensicherungskonzept and SYS.1.8 Speicherlösungen
data-loss-on-fileserver.mitigation: Ensure the file server asset is configured with hardware redundancy (e.g., a RAID system). This can be modeled by setting the
data-loss-on-fileserver.detectionLogic: Triggers for all in-scope technical assets of the
data-loss-on-fileserver.riskAssessment: The impact of data loss is driven by the file server

ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.title: Ransomware Infection via Lateral Movement
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.description: Ransomware is malware that encrypts data on infected systems, making it inaccessible, and attackers demand a ransom for decryption keys.
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.impact: If ransomware spreads from a less critical asset (e.g., a user workstation) to a central data store, it can encrypt large volumes of shared data.
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.asvs: Aligned with BSI IT-Grundschutz, especially APP.3.3 Fileserver threat scenarios involving malware/ransomware and the need for controls such as CON.3 (Malware Protection), CON.4 (Data Backup), and OPS.1.1.4 (Network Segmentation and Filtering).
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.action: Implement network segmentation, the principle of least privilege, and robust backup and recovery strategies
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.mitigation: To mitigate this risk, apply a defense-in-depth strategy:
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.check: Are write permissions to shared data stores strictly limited based on business need? Are client networks segmented from server/storage networks? Are regular, tested, offline/immutable backups in place for all critical data?
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.detectionLogic: This risk is identified when a less protected technical asset (e.g., a client or web application) has a non-read-only communication link to a high-value data store (such as a fileserver). This creates a potential path for ransomware to spread from a common infection point to critical data storage, bypassing protections on the data store itself.
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.riskAssessment: The likelihood is driven by the exposure of the initial asset (clients and internet-facing systems are more likely to be compromised). The impact depends on the availability and integrity requirements of the data on the target data store. A successful attack on a data store with mission-critical data has a very high impact.
ransomware-infection-via-lateral-movemen.falsePositives: A risk might be flagged as a false positive if compensating controls that are not modeled exist, such as an advanced EDR/XDR solution that effectively blocks ransomware

inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.title: Risiken bei Netzwerkkapazität und Latenz für virtualisierte Clients und kritische Verbindungen (BSI SYS.2.5)
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.description: Fehlende oder unzureichende Planung der Netzwerkkapazität und Latenz für Verbindungen zu und von virtuellen Clients (oder anderen kritischen Komponenten) kann die Funktionalität und Geschäftsabläufe beeinträchtigen. Im Kontext des BSI sind Terminal-/Remote-Desktop-ähnliche Workloads besonders empfindlich gegenüber Latenz und Jitter; unterdimensionierte Verbindungen zu Benutzern oder Backend-Diensten (Dateidienste, Datenbanken, Verzeichnisdienste und Konferenzsysteme) verursachen Einfrieren, Timeouts und Dienstunterbrechungen.
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.impact: Eingeschränkter oder instabiler Zugriff auf Dienste, träge Benutzeroberfläche, erhöhte Fehlerraten und Timeouts – was letztendlich die Verfügbarkeit beeinträchtigt. Für Endbenutzer äußert sich dies in langsamen, nicht reagierenden oder unbrauchbaren Anwendungen; bei Backend-Systemen kann dies zu festgefahrenen Threads, Warteschlangenstau und Teilausfällen führen.
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.asvs: Basiert auf BSI IT-Grundschutz SYS.2.5 Client-Virtualisierung und SYS.1.6 Virtualisierung; bezieht sich auf die Gefährdung „T 4.29: Unzureichende Netzanbindung von virtuellen Maschinen“. Die fiktive Anforderungs-ID
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.action: Bandbreite/Latenz/QoS für alle kritischen Verbindungen dokumentieren, bereitstellen und überprüfen.
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.mitigation: Identifizieren und dokumentieren Sie Bandbreiten-, Latenz-, Jitter- und Paketverlust-SLOs für Endbenutzer- und Backend-Pfade. Stellen Sie ausreichende Kapazität und QoS (einschließlich DSCP/klassenbasiertem Queuing, wo anwendbar) bereit. Vermeiden Sie Überbuchung. Testen Sie vor der Inbetriebnahme mit synthetischer Last und realen Benutzerwegen. Überwachen Sie kontinuierlich (APM/NPM) und alarmieren Sie bei SLO-Verletzungen. Für durch diese Regel markierte Verbindungen, legen Sie explizit Nachweise vor, dass das Netzwerk die erwartete Spitzennachfrage erfüllt.
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.check: Haben kritische Verbindungen definierte Bandbreiten-/Latenz-/Jitter-SLOs und Bemessungsberechnungen? Ist QoS konfiguriert und End-to-End validiert (einschließlich WAN/Cloud-Edges)? Sind Performance-Dashboards/Alerts vorhanden und werden sie überprüft, mit Handlungsanweisungen (Runbooks) für Leistungsabfälle?
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.detectionLogic: Wird für jede nicht-lokale Kommunikationsverbindung ausgelöst, die entweder (1) explizit mit @Latency:Critical getaggt ist oder (2) mindestens ein Daten-Asset mit Mission-Critical-Verfügbarkeit transportiert. Lokale, nicht-netzwerkbasierte Interaktionen (In-Process-Aufrufe oder lokaler Dateizugriff) sind ausgeschlossen. Die Auswirkung leitet sich aus der höchsten Verfügbarkeit der Verbindung oder des Ziels ab; wenn eine Client-Technologie beteiligt ist, wird die Auswirkung aufgrund der benutzerseitigen Effekte minimal erhöht.
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.riskAssessment: Wahrscheinlichkeit: Standardmäßig 'Wahrscheinlich' für latenzempfindliche oder geschäftskritische (mission-critical) Abläufe, da Leistungseinbußen ohne explizite Kapazitätsplanung häufig sind. Auswirkung: abgeleitet aus der maximalen Verfügbarkeit des Ziel-Assets und der Verbindung; Mission-Critical-Abläufe werden als 'Hohe' Auswirkung eingestuft. Eine Beteiligung auf der Benutzerseite (Client) hebt die Untergrenze auf mindestens 'Mittel' an.
inadequate-network-performance-for-virtu.falsePositives: Akzeptabel, wenn Sie auf aktuelle Kapazitätspläne, QoS-Konfigurationen, Last-/Latenztestergebnisse und Live-Überwachung verweisen können, die Reserven unter Spitzen- und Ausfallszenarien nachweisen. In solchen Fällen dokumentieren Sie die Nachweise und erwägen Sie, die Instanz als mitigiert zu kennzeichnen.

insufficient-virtual-client-resources.title: Unzureichende Ressourcen für virtuelle Clients (BSI SYS.2.5 – Gefährdung 2.2, Anforderung A10)
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.description: Virtuelle Desktop-/Client-Workloads (VDI) erfordern ausreichend CPU, RAM, Speicher-IOPS, GPU und Netzwerkdurchsatz. Wenn ein virtueller Client unterdimensioniert ist oder um gemeinsam genutzte Ressourcen konkurriert, verlangsamen sich benutzerseitige Anwendungen oder starten nicht, was sich direkt auf den Geschäftsbetrieb auswirkt.
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.impact: Ein Leistungseinbruch bei virtuellen Clients beeinträchtigt die Verfügbarkeit von Benutzer-Workflows: längere Anmeldezeiten, eingefrorene Anwendungen, fehlerhaftes Rendering und Timeouts bei nachgelagerten Diensten. Bei hochverfügbaren Rollen kann dies kritische Prozesse und die Produktivität ganzer Teams zum Erliegen bringen.
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.asvs: BSI-Zuordnung: SYS.2.5 Client-Virtualisierung – 2.2 Ressourcenknappheit; SYS.2.5.A10 Bedarfsgerechte Zuweisung von Ressourcen.
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.action: Ressourcen für virtuelle Clients (VDI) richtig dimensionieren und garantieren.
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.mitigation: Definieren Sie persona-basierte Ressourcenprofile; reservieren Sie minimale CPU/RAM/IOPS; ermöglichen Sie eine dynamische Anpassung der Größe mit überwachten Obergrenzen; weisen Sie GPUs nur bei Bedarf zu/virtualisieren Sie sie; erstellen Sie Baselines und Warnmeldungen für CPU-, RAM-, IOPS-, GPU- und Netzwerksättigung; verwenden Sie Ressourcenpools, Reservierungen, Limits und Anteile; verhindern Sie verschachtelte Virtualisierung; halten Sie Vorlagen aktuell und gehärtet.
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.check: Sind die Baselines für CPU/RAM/IOPS/GPU/Netzwerk pro Rolle dokumentiert? Sind Reservierungen/Limits/Anteile auf der Virtualisierungsplattform konfiguriert? Ist eine Überwachung mit Schwellenwerten und Warnmeldungen für VDI-Sitzungen und Hosts aktiv? Sind die Benutzer über die gleichzeitige starke Nutzung aufgeklärt?
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.detectionLogic: Löst einen Befund für jedes im Geltungsbereich befindliche technische Asset aus, bei dem machine === Virtual UND technology ∈ {ClientSystem, Desktop} gilt. Schließt Assets außerhalb des Geltungsbereichs aus. Die Auswirkung wird durch die Verfügbarkeitsanforderung des Assets skaliert. Bestimmt für VDI/virtuelle Desktop-/Client-Systeme, die unter Ressourcenkonflikten oder Unterdimensionierung leiden könnten.
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.riskAssessment: Wahrscheinlichkeit: Wahrscheinlich – Ressourcenkonflikte und falsche Dimensionierung sind in virtuellen Desktop-Umgebungen häufig. Auswirkung: abgeleitet aus der Verfügbarkeit des Assets (MissionCritical → Hoch; Critical/Important → Mittel; sonst Niedrig).
insufficient-virtual-client-resources.falsePositives: Geringes Risiko, wenn strikte Reservierungen und dedizierte Ressourcenpools eine Mindestleistung garantieren (z. B. vCPU-/Speicherreservierungen, dedizierte GPUs, nachgewiesene Reserven) und eine kontinuierliche Leistungsüberwachung keine Sättigung unter Spitzenlast zeigt.

resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.title: Ressourcenerschöpfung auf der Virtualisierungsplattform (BSI CON.5)
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.description: Virtualisierungs-Hosts konsolidieren viele Clients auf gemeinsam genutzten CPU, RAM, Speicher und I/O. Ohne sorgfältige Kapazitätsplanung und Limits können konkurrierende Tenants um Ressourcen kämpfen, was zu unvorhersehbaren Verlangsamungen oder Ausfällen von virtuellen Clients führt, insbesondere bei dynamischer Zuweisung oder stoßweisen Workloads.
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.impact: Erschöpfte Host-Ressourcen beeinträchtigen oder stoppen alle VMs auf diesem Host/Cluster. Dies führt zu einer Verlangsamung des Dienstes oder zu einem Denial-of-Service für abhängige Anwendungen, was hauptsächlich die Verfügbarkeit und indirekt die Integrität beeinträchtigt (z. B. Timeouts, fehlgeschlagene Schreibvorgänge).
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.asvs: ASVS V13.2.1: Überprüfen Sie, ob die Anwendung widerstandsfähig gegen Ressourcenerschöpfungsangriffe ist.
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.action: Führen Sie Host-Kapazitätsplanung, pro-VM-Quoten/Reservierungen und proaktive Überwachung/Alarmierung ein.
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.mitigation: Dimensionieren Sie Hosts für Spitzenlasten mit Reserven; konfigurieren Sie pro-VM CPU-/Speicherreservierungen und harte Limits; kontrollieren Sie Noisy-Neighbor-Effekte (Anteile/Limits); überwachen Sie kontinuierlich die Host- und VM-Auslastung mit Warnmeldungen; testen Sie Failover und Live-Migration; isolieren oder dedizieren Sie Hosts für kritische Tenants; bevorzugen Sie HA-Cluster für Ausfallsicherheit.
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.check: Sind CPU-/Speicherreservierungen/-limits pro VM festgelegt? Wird die Cluster-/Host-Auslastung mit Warnmeldungen und SLOs überwacht? Sind HA-/Live-Migrationsfunktionen aktiviert und getestet? Sind kritische Workloads von allgemeinen Tenants isoliert? Gibt es einen dokumentierten Kapazitätsplan mit regelmäßigen Überprüfungen und Stresstests?
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.detectionLogic: Wird für jede Shared Runtime ausgelöst, die mehr als ein technisches Asset im Geltungsbereich ausführt (Assets außerhalb des Geltungsbereichs werden ignoriert). Die Wahrscheinlichkeit skaliert mit der Anzahl der Tenants: ≤3 ⇒ Unwahrscheinlich, 4–7 ⇒ Wahrscheinlich, >7 ⇒ Sehr wahrscheinlich. Die Auswirkung ist die maximale Verfügbarkeitsanforderung unter den Tenants: Important ⇒ Mittel, Critical ⇒ Hoch, Mission-Critical ⇒ Sehr hoch. Der kritischste Tenant wird als am relevantesten hervorgehoben. Single-Tenant Shared Runtimes lösen dieses Risiko nicht aus.
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.riskAssessment: Mehr Tenants auf einem Host erhöhen die Wahrscheinlichkeit von Konkurrenz; wenige Tenants machen es unwahrscheinlich, viele Tenants machen es sehr wahrscheinlich. Die Auswirkung spiegelt den höchsten Verfügbarkeitsbedarf unter den Co-Tenants wider, sodass das Vorhandensein einer geschäftskritischen VM die Auswirkung auf sehr hoch anhebt, auch wenn andere weniger kritisch sind.
resource-exhaustion-on-virtualization-pl.falsePositives: Kann ein False Positive sein, wenn harte Reservierungen/Limits die Kapazität garantieren, Hosts einem einzigen kritischen Tenant gewidmet sind oder ein HA-/Autoscaling-Cluster ausreichende Reserven unterhält, die durch Stresstests und SLOs validiert sind. Solche Zusicherungen erfordern in der Regel operative Nachweise, die über das Modell hinausgehen.

improper-virtual-network-segmentation-on.title: Unsachgemäße virtuelle Netzwerksegmentierung auf einem gemeinsam genutzten Host (BSI SYS.2.5 §2.4)
improper-virtual-network-segmentation-on.description: Virtuelle Clients mit unterschiedlichen Schutzbedürfnissen werden auf demselben Virtualisierungs-Host betrieben. Wenn virtuelle Netzwerkkomponenten (vSwitches/Portgruppen/VLANs/Uplinks) falsch konfiguriert sind, kann der Client-Verkehr unbeabsichtigte Segmente durchlaufen, was die beabsichtigte Netzwerktrennung untergräbt.
improper-virtual-network-segmentation-on.impact: Fehler in der virtuellen Netzwerksegmentierung können sensible Servernetzwerke für Client-Segmente freilegen und so unbefugten Zugriff, Datenoffenlegung, Manipulation und laterale Bewegungen ermöglichen. Das Zusammenlegen eines internet-zugänglichen Clients mit hochsicheren internen Netzwerken erhöht die Angriffsfläche der Institution erheblich.
improper-virtual-network-segmentation-on.asvs: In Anlehnung an BSI IT-Grundschutz: SYS.2.5 Client-Virtualisierung (insb. Abschnitt 2.4: Netztrennung), SYS.2.1 Allgemeiner Client, SYS.1.5 Virtualisierung und NET.1.1 Netzarchitektur & Design.
improper-virtual-network-segmentation-on.action: Strikte Netzwerksegmentierung auf der Virtualisierungsebene durchsetzen, überprüfen und kontinuierlich überwachen.
improper-virtual-network-segmentation-on.mitigation: Konfigurieren Sie vSwitches/Port-Gruppen/VLAN-Tags, um die modellierten Grenzen durchzusetzen. Bei gemischten Vertrauenszonen auf einem Host verwenden Sie separate virtuelle Switches oder eine starke, verifizierte Isolation (z. B. Mikrosegmentierung). Überprüfen Sie regelmäßig das Hypervisor-Netzwerk gegen die Zielarchitektur. Wenden Sie im Modell

Wenn ja, gibt es eine robuste, auditierte Trennung auf der Hypervisor-Ebene (korrekte vSwitch/VLAN-Platzierung, kein unbeabsichtigtes Bridging/Uplinks) und – falls zutreffend – eine dokumentierte Härtung (
improper-virtual-network-segmentation-on.detectionLogic: Für jede Shared Runtime ohne das Tag
improper-virtual-network-segmentation-on.riskAssessment: Die Auswirkung skaliert mit der Sensibilität und Kritikalität der gemischten Assets; das Mischen von internet-zugänglichen Clients mit vertraulichen oder kritischen Backends führt zu einer sehr hohen Auswirkung. Die Wahrscheinlichkeit ist
